text: Stop spreading misinformation, first of all, Arctic sea ice and Antarctic sea ice are different in many ways. Arctic sea ice before we had major anthropogenic (human-made) climate change would cause ice to melt and much of it would be intact leaving some older ice that has been in the region for a long time and especially during the summer. But in recent years because of our impact on fossil fuels and CO2, the percentage of intact ice in the Arctic has been decreasing by an average of 13.1% through the time period of 1979-2020. That means that we have an increase in the amount of water that will most likely cause issues and help create more anomalies in weather patterns. Also when we have permafrost and terrestrial ice like mountain snowcaps global warming is occurring many of the seasonal ice formations happen differently and there is more runoff and that is what will cause rising sea levels, not necessarily the ice already displacing water in the sea. These are issues and so not getting good evidence or cherry-picking evidence is not correct. Also, many of the ice actually reflects sunlight originally but the decreasing amounts of intact ice at certain times of the year cause heating because of the lack of presence.

text:
I‚Äòm all for objective reasoning. But some of the data he uses to prove his point is not correct which makes me suspicious. The percentage of global energy that comes from renewables was 18.1% in 2017 ( Renewables 2019 Global Status Report. (PDF; 14,8 MB) REN21, Pages 31‚Äì32 https://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/gsr_2019_full_report_en.pdf ). To discard building more photovoltaic, wind, power-to-gas and storage now (which often is cheaper already depending on the country) because some spread panic is a bad idea. I agree that spreading panic is counterproductive. I understand that some are lead to do it because they feel not enough is done to reduce the global CO2 output. I‚Äòm not against nuclear. But I believe renewables are overall a better long term strategy. Let‚Äôs combine both if that‚Äôs the best solution. Lifting the poor out of poverty is an amazing goal we should all work towards. That‚Äôs not an argument against doing the things already proven to help the climate. 
Such a tough topic though. It‚Äôs hard to know how follows which agenda and what sources are actually reliable.

text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

text: Hi Paul, actually that is not true. For thousands of years CO2 levels were in relative equilibrium. At the start of the industrial revolution they were at about 280ppm. In 1910 they reached 300ppm, a level not reached in the past 330,000 years. By 1961 they were about 316ppm. Today they are about 415ppm, a level not seen in millions of years. The reason for this is mankind's burning of fossil fuels has added a roughly 3% increase to the carbon flux. This may not seem like much, but it is just enough to tip the carbon cycle from equilibrium, to a state of accumulation. So CO2 levels aren't just rising, they are accelerating. Since the 1970's, solar irradiance has actually decreased, but temperatures have increased. Aerosol levels have also been increasing, but this should have a cooling effect on our planet's temperature, but that isn't what is happening. Rising CO2 levels are responsible for the increasing temperature.

I'm nearly 70.
I clearly remember the wild ALARMS sounded from the 50's to nearly the 90's about (wait for it.....) not Global warming but....
THE COMING ICE AGE !
Then sometime in the 90's these fools flipped their story to; OMG! THE POLAR ICE CAPS ARE MELTING! We're all going to be under WATER!
Since "accurate" temperature records only go back (even in the most advanced nations) about 100 or 120 years, and our planets natural climate cycles likely are hundreds, even THOUSANDS of years long, we have no idea what is part of some sort of "Natural Cycle" or what is; "TOTALLY MAN CAUSED CLIMATE CHANGE"!
Hint; if you got 1000 top experts in a room and told them we need to change our Global temperature by 1 degree in 50 or 100 years, THEY WOULD HAVE ZERO IDEA HOW WE COULD DO IT!
So stop with those ridiculous ALARM tactics. 
I personally think that it is AT LEAST a possibility that human activity "might" eventually be a small contributor to "climate change"! May be 1%, maybe 3%, there is NO WAY of knowing WITH ANY CERTAINTY!
But unless EVERYONE ON THIS PLANET cooperates, and returns to live in the year 1300 A.D. you can simply forget about having any significant effect on the final outcome. 
CHEERS!

text: Most people understand that the planet's topography and climate have changed dramatically.  Even in the last million years, heavy ice age glaciation was the norm, and certain to return long after we're dead.  Looking farther back, there was the separation of Pangea, over tens of millions of years, into the continents we know today, and climate that varied from no polar glaciation to "snowball Earth", long before our species even existed.  It's safe to say that the Earth with experience dramatic changes, long after we're gone, but for the time being we should feel lucky and happy to live in a time that's stable and hospitable, and understand that our species will be unable to prevent catastrophic events because those events involve forces far beyond anything our species could oppose, even if we tried.  Leave it to fools to waste their effort on that fool's errand.

text: Regarding climate change, the data simply doesn't fit an alarmist view demanding immediate human action. The climate is always changing, with or without human involvement. I'd argue that humans have very little influence on it. However, that doesn't mean we shouldn't be good stewards of the Earth. I think it's a great idea to promote increased environmental awareness (reduce consumption, reuse when possible, recycle when possible). However, I reject this demand for increased government intervention in the economy. Stop politicizing the issue.

text:
All those complaining in the comments section that this argument is incorrect or pedantic, I have a general knowledge test for you. 


1, What is the leading green house gas in the atmosphere and what is it's concentration in parts per million? 
2, What is the current percentage of Carbon Dioxide in the total of all green house gases? 
3, What is the standard deviation in reference to time when Al Gore attempted to make a comparison between Carbon Dioxide core ice samples and the temperature record?
4, How much did Al Gore claim the global temperature had risen from the 1940's to the year 2000? 
5, What was the temperature trend as recorded since the invention of the modern thermometer (roughly in the 17th century) and how does that compare to the current temperature trends? 
6, How many temperature reading stations are there on the continent of Antarctica? 
7, Has polar ice in the Antarctic been increasing or decreasing in mass over the past few decades? 
8, What is the optimal Carbon Dioxide level for plant photosynthesis? 
9, What is another name for the Plystecine Ice Age? 
10, Who was Thomas Gold and how could his theory, if proven correct, radically change our understanding of renewable energy resources? 


See the first comment for the correct answers


If you can answer all those questions correctly and you still think anthroprogenic climate change is a credible and immediate threat you either seriously need to rethink your position, or take an intro to logic class because someone obviously forgot to teach you how to think rationally.


In addition, this channel was started as part of a non profit organization by noted journalist Dennis Prager in order to challenge the "unhealthy effect intellectually and morally" of the American higher education system. The fact that it's putting a rather significant dent in the strangle hold that bias leftist media has over information on important topics is also rather commendable. I've done a lot of fact checking and determined that on balance they are extremely accurate and balanced, as good journalism should be.

author: MeMyselfAndI

text:
1, The leading green house gas is water vapor and it's atmospheric concentration changes depending on region but it usually stays between 10000 and 50000 ppm. Current back ground CO2 concentrations currently stand at around 250 to 350. 400 if you're in a heavily populated city. 
2, The current percentages of green house gases currently stand at Water Vapor in front with a commanding lead of 95%, Followed by CO2 at 3.7%, Methane takes the third spot at 0.8% with Ozone and trace CFCs coming in last at 0.5%
3, When Al Gore presented "An Inconvenient Truth." He argued that you could compare temperature records with CO2 deposits in core ice samples and compare them. Standard deviation is basically how much wiggle room is he allowing in his analysis. A good standard deviation would have been four months to a year. His standard deviation was several hundred to several thousand years. That sort of tactic is only used when people don't have a good correlation and want to fudge the data to make it look like there is one, (any statistical analyst will tell you that). 
4, Al Gore claimed that all the pollution that man has created cause dramatic increase in earth's temperatures. Well how much is it? According to his own information all the CO2 that we have produced from the industrial revolution to the year 2000 managed to increase average world temperatures by .... 0.8 degrees Farenheit. That's less than a degree in over one hundred years. Hardly alarming, in fact it would be pretty difficult to corroborate effectively. 
5, Ever since the end of the little ice age (roughly the 1800's) temperatures have been steadily increasing. When you take the entire temperature record into account there appears to be no significant increase in temperatures after the industrial revolution, and certainly not in the last half century. 
6, There are only seven temperature reading stations for the entire continent of Antarctica. That means that we only have seven points of data for the entire south pole region. When you working with statistical models like the kind they're supposedly using to predict climate change require thousands of data point to even approach being accurate, that decidedly underwhelming. 
7, It's true polar ice mass in the arctic has been decreasing but as far as we can tell polar ice mass in the antarctic has been increasing over the past several decades. 
8, What is the optimal Carbon Dioxide level for plant photosynthesis? We honestly don't know. No one has ever found it. We do know that it's starts to displace oxygen and therefore kill off animal life at around 40000 ppm. (Before you freak out remember that 100 times normal background levels in places like NY, LA, and Beijing.) 
9, Another name for the Plystecine Ice Age is .. the modern era. We are technically living at the tail end of a very mild ice age. If we didn't there wouldn't even be polar ice caps. 
10, Thomas Gold was scientist who started his career in Astrophysics. He did much of the ground breaking work that made Stephen Hawkings work possible. Because of a falling out with NASA in the 80's he shifted his scientific focus to geology and ended up conducting some incredible experiments and proposing a well supported if controversial theory. He managed to prove that under intense heat and pressure carbon and water will actually alter their bonds and form long chain hydrocarbons. He therefore theorized that the term fossil fuel is a misnomer and crude oil is in fact a by product of geological processes that occur in the earths mantle and eventually bubbles up back into the crust where he find it as crude oil. If this proves to be true then crude oil is a renewable resource, and subsequently the primary argument of climate change advocates regarding sustainability is invalid.

text:
This is the main beef I have with climate alarmists. I do not mind cutting carbon emissions. I do not mind walking to the store and back every day (assuming I'm not hauling a load back home). I do not mind saving power by turning off lights and heat in rooms that are unused. I might want to add that I am from Norway, so our power consumption is practically 100% green and renewable, but that power I DON'T use could have been sold to someone who only has polluting energy to take from. However, my beef comes when researchers, politicians and environmentalists start to encourage stifling economic growth and put all sorts of limitations on things that ACTUALLY have no real impact for their sake of feeling 'good' about themselves. 
They do not put their money where their mouth is. I'm a Mechanical Engineer with a heavy focus on Renewable energy, so I would WELCOME the idea of more resources to Renewable energy because that would secure me with a job for life. But all I am seeing is a lot of talk and a lot of pressure on the oil industry (which would be my other place of work given my degree), but absolutely no financial encouragement towards the other option. Basically I am only seeing my bread and butter being attacked with no other option opening once that attack succeeds.

text:
¬†@robert hicks¬† There is plenty of evidence. Look at the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and look at the relationship between that and carbon emission rates. This disruption of the carbon cycles affects many other aspects of thd biosphere, both directly and indirectly.

For example, the acidification of the oceans, which is caused by the uptake of carbon dioxide. CO2 takes part in many chemical reactions, which lowers the pH of the entire ocean overall. This hurts many species of the ocean, and has a devastating effect on calcifying species. Overall, this disrupts the entire ocean food web. And remember, no ecosystem is isolated. It affects all life on Earth. This is just one aspect. There are so many more.

Alarmism exists because this is a serious problem. It's causes more alarm from a scientific point of view. A 2 degree average increase in temperature doesn't sound like much, but that's a terrifying figure to scientists. Keyword: average.

text:
I would trust the scientist. Read peer review journals and see what the real scientist say. If¬† you don't know what is and what isn't a peer review science journal, here is a list. https://www.omicsonline.org/peer-reviewed-journals.php
Notice they do not list climatology peer review journals and Nature is not on their list. Climatology is a group of fields that includes pretty much every science in the world. Nature doesn't follow the rules that real peer review journals follow. Mainly, this is due to their allowing anyone to publish an article in the "field" of climatology, regardless of if it is in your field of expertise and to "request" a reviewer again disregarding if article is in their field.

An example of this is an article, written by Michael Mann, a Physicist concerning tree rings, something he had no expertise in. His claim was that it was about climatology, and he requested¬† two other climatologist, an astronomer and a chemist¬†by training, as the reviewer. NONE of them were experts in tree rings. A real expert in tree rings, called a Dendrochronologist, who by the way have their own peer review journals, would have tore it apart because there are too many factors that determine the size of tree rings for you to be able to use them to determine temperature.

To date Michael Mann has never shown his computer program that created that graph.

text:
It s a general truth that if a problem exists, then applying a nonworking solution to that problem will actually make matters worse, because the time and money devoted to the nonworking solution reduces the chance of finding a good solution. 

Currently, something of the order of $1.5 trillion is spent on climate change measures every year, a third of that on wind and solar installations. To complete the ITER fusion reactor would take around $30 billion (give or take) which is only a FEW DAYS' WORTH of the global wind and solar spend. A few days' worth. Think about the enormity of this waste of resources that could be put into finding a better solution. 

ITER is not the only advanced energy project, and might not even produce a solution, but consider the number of such projects which could be funded if we stopped wasting the money. One is bound to work, and we only need one. 

A major issue here is that the wind turbine marketers were, and still are, allowed to make snake-oil style exaggerated claims for their products. This should not go on. Other manufacturers have to be honest about the capabilities of their products. The Greens/Left would rather believe the exaggerations than the actual figures because the exaggerations suit their world-view, while the truth does not. Hence the Green politicians keep pushing this stuff.  

Intermittency is one of the biggest problems, and the marketers claim that battery storage WILL solve the intermittency. However, the batteries in question do not yet exist, and nobody knows if they can be invented. That doesn't faze the wind marketers in the slightest, who go ahead and put a small battery on the Australian Grid and claim that Australia now has battery back-up for wind. Well, OK it does, but just not of any useful size. A propaganda stunt, no more no less. 

We now have a situation where bids for ridiculously low strike prices have been taken to indicate that wind energy has become cheaper than coal. Yet, nobody has ever produced wind energy at those prices and stayed in business. Can the contract be fulfilled? It's these sorts of disinformation tactics which should ring alarm bells about this whole massively costly industry and the way it's squandering our chance of finding a real replacement for fossil fuels.

text: The dramatic decline in deaths is due to better lead-time from weather modeling and predictions.  Additionally, you shouldn't use death rates as a means to measure climate change impacts.  That's like rating fuel efficiency for a vehicle based on the number of passengers.  You should look at drought and flood statistics, and the number and intensity of weather events (hurricanes, tornadoes, etc.).  I get the point of the video, but it frames the argument and leaves out key details, like how much hydro-electric, geothermal, and nuclear energy sources also cut carbon emissions and should be lumped in with wind and solar.  Then the amount might be closer to 25%.

text:
Why would science predict that Antarctic sea ice is decreasing? I would expect the melting of the Antarctic glaciers would put more fresh water in the sea and increase sea ice.
But the climate isn't changing from bad to worse, it's changing from one state to another, and because of human activity it's happening faster than nature can adapt, leading to rapid species extinction. This collapse of the ecosystem is a definite problem and needs to be addressed. At the end of the Permian the warming was slower than our current rate, but it resulted in the extinction of 90% of all species.
Personal preference. I don't want to ignore the problem because "technology will solve everything" and then find out after the fact that one of the species that goes extinct is Homo sapiens.
Little late then to say, "Oops, we were wrong after all."

Antartic SEA ice is increasing but Antarctic LAND ice is decreasing. the reason is because land ice falls into the sea and melts, adding a lot of fresh water to the area, diluting the salt content of the water. and thus increasing it's freezing point.

This is process by which Antarctica is gaining sea ice, however it is important to remember that SEA ice (similar to ice blocks in your coca cola) is already in the ocean, so it has already raised the sea level.

text: Climate Change is real, but impossible to understand anymore, the politicians have hijacked the science. The left is in charge of the political and bureaucratic elites, the media, the universities, and Hollywood, so whether by design or it just happened that way, all the agencies in the government have been headed by leftists for a very long time. There is no balance, not when they manipulate the data collection. How do we really understand anything, the thermometer was not invented until the 1870s, was not widely distributed for a decade or two, and nobody ever started recording temperatures until two technological advances; the thermograph and radio, which liked to fill air time reporting the temperature, so they bought the thermographs. That was in the 1930s, so how do we know what happened before that? We don't, not with a degree of accuracy more than + or - 3 degrees. Three degrees would be disastrous, they say, but how do we know that? Yet with all the radio stations on the planet, we still only recorded temperatures on less than 1% of the surface, 40% of those were in the US. When did we start recording temperatures on the oceans? We still haven't done that, so 70% of the planet is ignored. So when did we start recording the surface temperatures with any degree of accuracy? 1979. Less than 40 years of data, and now they manipulate everything to fit some kind of political narrative. What are the limitations? 95% of the latent heat energy is stored in the oceans, and what does CO2 production by man have to do with that? Nothing. So what do we actually know right now, what can we take to the bank. Ocean levels are not rising at all, the parts of Miami where the surface is getting flooded were built on swamps, the ground is sinking naturally. So if we assume that the socialist idiots at the IPCC are right, the oceans will rise 2 100ths of an inch for the next 100 years. Rich people with homes on the beach might get their toes wet, the poor living in shacks on stilts only have 100 years to adapt. So explain the alarmism, when we can now accurately predict that the increase in CO2 is responsible for 6% greening of the planet. All plants and animals benefit from a warmer planet with more CO2, that is a provable fact, so get the damned lying politicians out of the science! I am comforted to know that that since the satellites have started collecting data, that the raw data shows no temperature change in the last 40 years. Their graphs showing anything else have been manipulated. The satellites are only accurate to within 2 degrees C, so how is it that they show hundredths of a degree difference?

text: I watched this clip multiple times, but what is his message? Climate change is not such a big problem but still a serious problem? Should or shouldn't we cut carbon emissions? We should stop investing in solar and wind energy (= green energy) and start investing in making green energy cheaper? His point that an 'alarmist' attitude towards climate change, prevents us to work on smart solutions, is unsubstantiated in this clip. Why does he think that? Because carbon emissions are still rising in China and India? That seems to me an ultra-superficial and opportunistic analysis, to put it mildly. And I don't see how less alarming communication can make them drop. This clip is from a university, right? The only thing I do agree with is that we should look for smart solutions to the climate change problem (solutions that are both effective and have as low economic cost as possible) and that climate policy should be fact based.

text: What a stupid tap dance around a topic that has so much good data now. The data was right there, all the climate change zealots should have noticed, DUH! There has been no climate change, none, zip, nada, NONE! The climate is incredibly stable! Taken the raw data from satellites, which only go back 38 years, there has not been a single degree of change, and yet the margin of error is two degrees. Do you get that? NONE! We do not have global records going back any further, all that is interpolation with margins of error of more than 3 degrees! WAKE UP! Before satellites, we only recorded 1% of the surface temperatures going back to 1933, nothing before that! Why? We had no thermographs, no radio stations keeping records, and then there was all the political interference in the USSR because they manipulated that data so the gov't would give them more food and fuel to survive the harsher winters that they had reported. That was fully 25% of the data we collected up until the collapse of the USSR, 1989. So what does all the real data show? NOTHING! We have increased CO2 from 280 PPM in the 1930s until 380 ppm in 2000, but no increase lately. We have a 25 year pause when we only have records going back 38 years! So what is all this about? This is purely a hoax, gullible zealots who are afraid of a debate, wanting more control over your money, dictating everything we do, because just about everything requires energy. If they are so concerned, then why are they flying those jets around to so many meetings using up the same CO2 emissions as a thousand regular folks, or a million poor people! Remember, to restrict Carbon emissions, which is actually greening our planet, you are telling that poor person in India who hasn't eaten in three days that they cannot buy a tractor to plow the ground or run a pump to get clean water, or to use a refrigerator, which might save their life! Get real! This is a big fat nothing burger!
author: Robert Carver

text: "fix climate change" ¬†climate has always changed. most of the earth is covered in moving water and the data collection methods of the past century to measure water temps have changed. today, averaging geographic pinpoints and adjusting for anomalies to come up with a global temp within a fraction of a degree is not as accurate as main stream media describes it. comparing today's estimated averages to the same estimates from 100 years ago, 200 years ago, etc, requires a mathematical charlatan. even the comparison of geographic pinpoints on land over time has neglected to account for variables like increase in local concrete and nearby machinery and exhaust, etc. the margin of error included in ipcc reports for their own climate average estimates is large enough to more than nullify their findings. the measurement of change in global temps over decades is not the exact science that mainstream media present it to be. attributing a portion of whatever change there is to CO2 is even more science fiction than science, as less than 2% of total global CO2 is anthropomorphic. the rest is natural. if all human beings eliminated all human related CO2 production (including ceasing to exhale) it would not reduce total CO2 by more than 2%, and only a charlatan would pretend to be able to predict what effect that would have on the global climate and any gradual change that may be occurring. their climate models attempting to make predictions over decades are bad enough as it is. now estimate humans could eliminate 1/3 of all human related CO2, an ambitious goal. because about 98% of CO2 production is natural, that significant drop in anthropomorphic CO2 only accounts for less than 1% of all CO2 combined. pretending to predict the effect that would have on questionably accurate climate change estimates requires suspension of all critical cognitive function. ¬†how would the elimination of 1/3 of human related CO2 affect the global economy, which is how people get fed and housed and clothed and watch youtube vids? that is much easier to quantify. it would kill millions.

text:
How on earth can you say Global Warming is Climate Change?
They are two separate natural unstoppable disasters that will eventually happen. 
Global Warming happens after every ice age but, because we are still not out of our last ice age, it has not started yet.
for the last 10 yeas NASA as been taking photographs of the North Pole and has documented a 60% increase of ice. In the Plateau regions of the Antarctic it has not been warmer then -20 degrees Celsius and only on the coastal areas you may find 0 degrees Celsius or maybe even 1 or 2 degrees Celsius in the high summer time. In the dark ages it was possible to grow wine in most parts of the United Kingdom but, because of a temperature drop since the dark ages, this is no longer possible. Also if Global Warming would be happening and the Sea level is rising, why is this not noticeable at all Ports world wide? I am also sure that the first country who would vanish is the Netherlands and then the United Kingdom. If that is the case and this disaster is on its way, how come the financial industry is still giving out 30-40 year Mortgages to people in the United Kingdom or the Netherlands or North Germany or The southern part of the United States of America? Because its a scam and the Banks know it is. They know in 10 years time that very expensive house in Cornwall will still be there. In the 1970s most scientists said that in about 50 - 60 years time we should experience a small ice age created by the greenhouse effect. Now the main reason why the politicians of western Society are so keen on pushing for Global Warming is to slow down economic Growth in third world countries. Could you imagine what would happen to the western co-operations, the super companies like Nestle if India or Bolivia would be economically stable? This can not happen and they will do anything to stop it. One main way is to pay politicians to support their cause and create International Laws to stop third world countries from growing out of poverty. If any country would ignore the new laws passed through without their say so, we would simply intervene with military action in the name of freedom and to save the world after we use depleted uranium to destroy their army like in Iraq. Ok so maybe WWF have shown clips of large amounts of ice breaking away and they will continue that to get your money but, have you ever thought about how high must the North and South Pole must be if it constantly snows there and or its solid. Snow falls onto land and piles up. Pressure of that large amount starts to push the snow or ice out towards the coast. Saltwater and a slight higher temperature starts to melt the ice and WWF film this and sell it everyone as disastrous. I did not want to point fingers at WWF but, they are the first ones that came through my mind.  

Climate Change is also a natural disaster that is not stoppable by mankind. This is caused by the Magnetic Field and the movement of the Magnetic North. As you may of heard before, our planet is surrounded by a Magnetic Field that protects us from a lot of harmful things like Ultra Violet Rays from the sun and radioactive cosmic dust to name two. Our atmosphere is approximately 550KM thick (does not just stop, it thins out) and consists of four layers during the day (D, E, F1 & F2) and only one layer at night. (D, E disappear and F1 & F2 merge together) There are three types of Norths we use and the first one is the True North. This is where Santa and his Elves make the Christmas Presents. The second one being the Grid North. This is used on a proper map where you have little squares that mark 1KM¬≤ or 2KM¬≤ and are called Grid Squares. You just cant put a Grid over something that is round, somewhere it would be off. Finally we have the Magnetic North and this one is moving from west to east. Anyone who can read a proper map knows about the GMA (Grid Magnetic Angle) and that if you want to walk on a bearing from a map, you need to add the GMA on to the Mils or Degrees of your compass. That Magnetic North moving and the South staying where it is, is causing the Magnetic Field in the north-western Hemisphere to stretch and in the east-western side to bunch up. The stretching of the Magnetic Field is causing it to weaken off and that is why there is a large increase of Hurricanes, Tornados and extreme Lightning Storms happening around the United States of America. We also have seen abnormal behavior within animals like Fish and Birds that rely on the Magnetic Field for navigation. Sooner or later we with have a change in the position of our planet and we then may experience todays climate in Italy, in Germany.  I am sure everyone knows that the Antarctic was not always covered in snow.

Now what I will say is that we are responsible for a lot of bad things. We chop down our source of oxygen, we poison our oceans with plastic and our drinking water with chemicals and yes the Ozone Hole (in the E Layer of our atmosphere)  is us as well however, it has been shrinking. We are also responsible for our beaches disappearing but, that has nothing to do with water level rising, its more a thing about building things and needing sand to do so however, that‚Äôs a different topic.  So please relax and concentrate on the good things in life. Do something good, help someone in need and forget all this political bullcrap. Thanks for reading.

text:
0:28 "Antarctic sea ice is increasing"  Name Earth's largest natural ice machine (hint: its a continent the size of the U.S. and Mexico combined covered in ice 2 miles thick, which is now melting.  Where, or where, is that ice going to go?)
0:32 "yes sea levels are rising, but the rise is not accelerating"  Name Earth's largest natural thermometer.  Its a liquid contained in a basin that, when heated, expands.  ANY sea level rise is PROOF of Global Warming.  IF the planet is warming, THEN this should warm Polar ice sheets, causing them eventually to slip into the ocean.  We looked: its happening.  Also, 2+2 still equals 4, so do the math.
2:00 "we are told that things are getting worse, but the facts do not support this"  Lomborg's Hurricane data is looking pretty dated in light of last season's damages.  If you want facts on damages, google 'munich re weather catastrophes and climate change'.  Munich Re is a global re-insurance agency, and obviously they care about climate change damages: they have to pay for them.  Munich Re is screaming at the top of their lungs about climate change, and have been for decades now.  They have the statistics to back up their concern.  Also, after Hurricane Harvey, MIT climate scientist Kerry Emmanuel did an attribution study.  He determined that the rainfall levels of Harvey over Houston were a 2000 year storm event, in the last century, but will be a 100 year storm event by the end of THIS century.  I frankly trust Emmanuel (one of the worlds top experts on Hurricanes) over Lomborg, a paid 'climate pollyanist'.

Prager U: horrible propaganda.  What do you hope to gain from lying to your audience?  Nothing good can come of it.

text: ¬†@John Boehmer¬† Get your information correct please. The main reason the ice age narrative got any real attention is because Time magazine did a cover story talking about a few published papers that made a global cooling claim; in reality, only 7 papers predicted cooling while 42 predicted warming during the 70s. text: We cannot change the weather. CO2 is a RESULT of global warming - NOT the cause. H2O is 95% of the greenhouse gas in the atmosphere. CO2 is only a minute percentage of greenhouse gases, and humans contribute very little of this. IF greenhouse gases were causing GW, we would see consistent rising temperatures in the upper atmosphere. yet, any change is coming from the surface, consistent with RADIANT energy from the SUN. solar winds blow away the clouds, allowing more energy to warm the surface. CO2 absorbed by the ocean is released in much the same way as a warm fizzy-drink does. The earth goes through cycles. 180-900ppm. currently 400ppm as we come out of the last ice-age. global temperatures were much warmer during the middle ages. they were even able to grow grapes in the north of england. it was a time of great prosperity.

text:
This is actually an excellent video. I choose not to identify with a Left or Right leaning, but I am often angry at how the Right treat climate change. I absolutely agree that we need to develop cheaper renewable energy, so that everyone will choose renewables over fossil fuels, especially the developing nations. I think many scientists and alarmists behave the way they do because of exactly what you said, they are worried the public won't do anything. The real way to solve the problem is with economics, make photovoltaics and wind cheaper. When they become cheaper (which they will if we invest), then we can fix this climate problem which will damage us in the LONG term, but isn't necessarily doing huge damage at the moment.

Unlike previous PragerU videos, this one spoke to me in a way that felt more fair. I still felt there is a bit of data picking and some misleading information, but the message was true in my opinion.

 Thank you.

text: Subsidies CAN improve and lower the cost of green energy though. If it comes to developing finished products, the private sector is often better than state-funded research. As a result, a lot of German solar companies popped up at first. Then the chinese realized that they could make money out of it and started to produce solar panels at a far cheaper price than was possible before, which increased the use of solar panels worldwide. text:
¬†@Ed Bailey¬† the thickness of a penny.
Multiplied by the water surface area of earth, which is .71*5.1*10^8 km^2 or 3.6*10^14 m^2. Doing the math, that's 3.6*10^14*1.5*10^-3 = 5.4*10^11 m^3 of water. Since one cubic millimeter of water is one milliliter, that's 5.4*10^14 liters of water or written for effect 540,000,000,000,000 liters. Basically, when you divide a big number by another big number, you get a smaller number, but that doesn't mean the first number was any less big.

text:
Absolutely fantastic.  For 6 years now I felt like a dog barking in the night, when it came to saying  "Hey don't use ~maybe bans~ as  the excuse to ~later~ put ~on other peoples shoulders~  the ~maybe better green energy tech~ subject.   Should start with the green energy tech and then steam roll opponents."     Now I feel like my words are more comprehensible and worth while to contribute!

That said, the subject of climate change is heated topic mainly because people identify they as individuals have little consequential control.  Therefore dialog at the highest levels reflects those of people who have no serious investment toward a solution despite emotional flaring.    It is used in small communities to work out social structure, which introduces anomalies/complications when people can "unfriend and block" + millions of people to replace them, and exercise reasoning skills on things that immediate choices wont cause any foreseeable harm.  Public bathrooms for example would be a good target  to huddle around.   Innovating how to rewire your entire house, not so much. 

 The human condition is very interesting!

text:
Even if there is ONE outlier of a paper with proper methodological execution, which stands against the so-called consensus, there is cause to consider upping the scope so that all related arguments can be included.

With that said, this video urges the average non-scientists to stop viewing Climate Change as a doomsday story about to come true, but rather to focus on helping THE MOST NEGATIVELY AFFLICTED: poor people who do not have the choices of grocery you and I have, let alone a consideration of eco-friendly products.

Take China for example, as things stand the majority of the people and their industrial complex have NO INCENTIVE to opt for greener manufacturing methods. They WILL knowingly keep burning unrefined dirty coal and the world along with it if it means their economy can keep growing fast. Their priorities are not necessarily the same as ours, but what are we going to do? Try to force them? The thought alone is preposterous and foolish. Bill Gates spoke about this matter, as many other big investors in ‚Äúbetter‚Äù tech.

Focusing on solar & other advanced tech feels awesome for us but on the true global scale that doesn‚Äôt help as much as we‚Äôd like.

Also, you mentioned hydroelectricity. Well, the gigantic dams that China built have flooded the entire surrounding habitats and will periodically intensify the flooding problems all the way down-river in the delta regions whenever Mother Nature has a sneeze. A gallon in a gallon out, with fewer trees to slow down the process after the dams were built. The economic damage might be ‚Äúsmall‚Äù in dollar count, but I don‚Äôt have to tell you why it matters to the poor folks with cheap housing in the floodplain.

All of the headlines about fuel cells, batteries, panels, etc. will not matter to those with half the income of your average broke waiters. And these people outnumber the rest 3-fold at least if I pulled figures out of my a** right. (Sorry)

PragerU promoted this message many times: don‚Äôt do it just to feel good. Do good instead. Their arguments in this video were consistent that way.

Knowledgeable people already know how to look for scientific information about what can be done and what can‚Äôt be done, but the voice of the masses seemed not to reflect that, hence a video like this.

text:
Then why do so many informed scientists think that climate change is a serious problem and/or a threat to humanity? Maybe the non-scientist in this video should ask these scientists. That might help him address his "What's So Alarming" question.


Among AAAS (American Academy for the Advancement of Science) scientists with relevant expertise, there's a 95% consensus that climate change was a serious problem and a 93% consensus that recent warming is mostly caused by humans:

"Earth Scientists Views on Climate Change"
http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/07/23/elaborating-on-the-views-of-aaas-scientists-issue-by-issue/

And in another survey, ~87% of climate researchers thought that humans caused (or will cause) most of the recent (or near future) climate change, while ~86% of climate researchers thought that climate change poses a very serious problem and a threat to humanity:

Figures 88 (v043) and 2 (v007) of "The Bray and von Storch 5th International Survey of Climate Scientists 2015/2016"
https://www.hzg.de/imperia/md/content/hzg/zentrale_einrichtungen/bibliothek/berichte/hzg_reports_2016/hzg_report_2016_2.pdf

Furthermore, there are various government institutions, scientific organizations, etc. who accept the seriousness of climate change and humanity's substantial effect on climate. Here are some of sources on this:

https://climate.nasa.gov/scientific-consensus/
http://www.ucsusa.org/global_warming/science_and_impacts/science/scientific-consensus-on.html#.WMIPtvnys2w
https://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/syr/AR5_SYR_FINAL_SPM.pdf
"Climate Change Evidence & Causes: An overview from the Royal Society and the US National Academy of Sciences"
"National Security Implications of Climate-related Risks and a Changing Climate"

In addition to being selective, their logic is also internally inconsistent."
http://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.0040256

"Characteristics of denialism
Identification of conspiracies: Denialists argue that scientific consensus arises not as a result of independent researchers converging on the same view but instead because researchers have engaged in a complex and secretive conspiracy. They are depicted as using the peer review process to suppress dissent rather than fulfil its legitimate role of excluding work that is devoid of evidence or logical thought."
http://www.bmj.com/content/341/bmj.c6950.full

"Denialism is a process that employs some or all of five characteristic elements in a concerted way. The first is the identification of conspiracies. When the overwhelming body of scientific opinion believes that something is true, it is argued that this is not because those scientists have independently studied the evidence and reached the same conclusion. It is because they have engaged in a complex and secretive conspiracy. The peer review process is seen as a tool by which the conspirators suppress dissent, rather than as a means of weeding out papers and grant applications unsupported by evidence or lacking logical thought."
https://academic.oup.com/eurpub/article/19/1/2/463780/Denialism-what-is-it-and-how-should-scientists

text:
A straw man is a common form of argument and is an informal fallacy based on giving the impression of refuting an opponent's argument, while refuting an argument that was not advanced by that opponent. One who engages in this fallacy is said to be "attacking a straw man".

1) You just used the straw man on me. I didn't say anything about the facts being wrong. I said he used the straw man fallacy.

2) 1:11 He tried to refute the premise that 'Hurricanes are used as an example of things getting worse' with a chart showing that Hurricane damage during the period of 1900s to the 2000s has decreased.

Damage decrease during the period of 1900 and 2000s doesn't disprove that climate is getting warmer and things are getting worse. 

It just shows that technology helps lower damage - obviously since technology has greatly improved since 1900. 

I didn't say the facts were wrong - I said that they are being misused. 

Now that you understand what I mean, look at the video again and you will be able to point a couple more.

author: snek

text:
+CAGW Scam

"The disconfirmed CAGW hypothesis projected ECS to be 3C to 4.5C, which is now known to be 100.00% impossible. Skeptics think ECS will be around 0.6C to 1C, which is PRECISELY what is being observed."

Looks like you're trying to deceive even more people with your nonsense. A few points:


1) Drop your CAGW straw man:

"Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial
[...]
Additionally, we find that catastrophic anthropogenic global warming [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a straw man used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)."



2) Plenty of scientific sources has shown a transient climate sensitivity (TCS) or an equilibrium climate sensitivity (ECS) greater than 3. For example, see:

"On a minimal model for estimating climate sensitivity
[...]

[...] the method of LS14 underestimates climate sensitivity by about 13%, correcting the estimates from the previous section, the credible intervals for transient climate response and equilibrium climate sensitivity are 1.292‚Äì2.937 and 2.330‚Äì5.338C respectively."

"Spread in model climate sensitivity traced to atmospheric convective mixing
[...]
The mixing inferred from observations appears to be sufficiently strong to imply a climate sensitivity of more than 3 degrees for a doubling of carbon dioxide. This is significantly higher than the currently accepted lower bound of 1.5 degrees, thereby constraining model projections towards relatively severe future warming."



3) An ECS of 0.6C to 1C is outside the range supported by the vast majority of the scientific evidence. For example:

"Climate Sensitivity Uncertainty: When is Good News Bad? 
[...]
Despite significant advances in climate science and increased confidence in the accuracy of the range itself, the ‚Äúlikely‚Äù range has been 1.5-4.5C for over three decades. In 2007, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) narrowed it to 2-4.5C, only to reverse its decision in 2013, reinstating the prior range."

author: CAGW Scam

text:
+Jack Crawford

"the drop in momentary damage of hurricane is probably a result of structures being more resistant to inclement weather, rather than a drop of the severity or frequency of hurricanes"

Notice that Lomborg didn't provide a citation for that hurricane damage claim he made around 1:26? I suspect that's because he's relying on his own crappy analysis. More reputable analyses show an increase in economic losses from hurricanes, even when one accounts for socioeconomic factors:

"Economic losses from US hurricanes consistent with an influence from climate change
[...]
We identify an upward trend in economic losses between 1900 and 2005 that cannot be explained by commonly used socioeconomic variables. Based on records of geophysical data, we identify an upward trend in both the number and intensity of hurricanes in the North Atlantic basin as well as in the number of loss-generating tropical cyclone records in the United States that is consistent with the smoothed global average rise in surface air temperature."


Anyway, there's some research suggesting that anthropogenic climate change has not significantly affected total hurricane frequency, but has augmented hurricane intensity:

"Recent intense hurricane response to global climate change"


And this review discusses increased hurricane intensity in various regions of the world:

"Tropical cyclones and climate change
[...]
For example, a summary of trends in the lifetime maximum intensity of TCTCs [tropical cyclones] in various ocean basins is shown in Figure 1, for the period 1989‚Äì2009. Globally, there are modest significant trends in this quantity (at the 90% level), but individual basins have greater significance. In the North Atlantic and Western North Pacific, trends are highly significant at the 95% level, with increases in the North Atlantic and decreases in the Western North Pacific. More modest trends significant at the 90% level are seen in the South Pacific and the South Indian basins (both upwards). Trends have not been significant in the Eastern North Pacific and the North Indian basin has insufficient data."

author: kestrel archer

text:
Taking a moderate tone, or claiming that you're in a moderate position between extremists (ex: between alarmists on one side, and denialists), doesn't mean your position is rational or right. To say otherwise, is a fallacious argument to moderation. Sometimes, one side of the debate is right, the other side is wrong, and the middle position(s) are wrong as well. Period.



Anyway, you lose credibility when you don't provide clear citations to the papers you're referencing, so people can read the papers for themselves and see if you're representing them accurately.



"But look at the U.S., where we have the best statistics: if we adjust for population and wealth, hurricane damage during the period of 1900-2013 actually decreased slightly."

You lose credibility when you make a claim that contradicts the published scientific literature, and you don't cite supporting evidence for your claim. In this case, that means side-stepping research showing increasing economic losses from hurricanes, even after controlling for socioeconomic factors:

"Economic losses from US hurricanes consistent with an influence from climate change
[...]
We identify an upward trend in economic losses between 1900 and 2005 that cannot be explained by commonly used socioeconomic variables. Based on records of geophysical data, we identify an upward trend in both the number and intensity of hurricanes in the North Atlantic basin as well as in the number of loss-generating tropical cyclone records in the United States that is consistent with the smoothed global average rise in surface air temperature."



"Yet the trend for strong typhoons around the Philippines have actually declined since 1950, according to a study published in 2012 by the Journal of Climate."

You lose credibility when you don't take into account reviews of tropical cyclone activity, including research showing increasing maximum intensity for typhoons in multiple regions of the world:

"Tropical cyclones and climate change
[...]
For example, a summary of trends in the lifetime maximum intensity of TCTCs [tropical cyclones] in various ocean basins is shown in Figure 1, for the period 1989‚Äì2009. Globally, there are modest significant trends in this quantity (at the 90% level), but individual basins have greater significance. In the North Atlantic and Western North Pacific, trends are highly significant at the 95% level, with increases in the North Atlantic and decreases in the Western North Pacific. More modest trends significant at the 90% level are seen in the South Pacific and the South Indian basins (both upwards). Trends have not been significant in the Eastern North Pacific and the North Indian basin has insufficient data."



"Yes, sea levels are rising, but the rise is not accelerating‚Äîif anything, two recent papers, one by Chinese scientists published in January 2014, and the other by U.S. scientists published in May 2013, have shown a small decline in the rate of sea-level increase."

You lose credibility when you get the time-frame of the acceleration wrong. The claim is not the rise accelerated in the past couple of years. That would be too small a sample size, and too prone to the effect of hard to control for stochastic control variables. That would make it difficult to get statistically significant results, as discussed in papers such as:

"Is the detection of accelerated sea level rise imminent?"
"Timescales for detecting a significant acceleration in sea level rise"

Instead, the point is that the rise since about the late 20th century, is greater than it was before then. Furthermore, some areas of the globe experience more accelerated sea level rise than other regions of the globe:

"A 20th century acceleration in global sea-level rise"
"Hotspot of accelerated sea-level rise on the Atlantic coast of North America"
"An Anomalous Recent Acceleration of Global Sea Level Rise"

Also remember that:
1) global warming causes sea level rise ["Global sea level linked to global temperature"]
2) there was global warming from about the 1970s to the present, with relative temperature stagnation (or slight global cooling) from the 1940s to the 1970s. ["Causes of the Global Warming Observed since the 19th Century"]

Given these two points, you'd expect the rate of sea level rise to change in response to global warming patterns of the 20th century. And that's what we observe:

"Recent global sea level acceleration started over 200 years ago?"



"But many climate-change alarmists seem to claim that all climate change is worse than expected. This ignores that much of the data is actually more encouraging than expected. [...] So let‚Äôs be clear. Climate change is not ‚Äúworse than we thought.‚Äù [...] But the narrative that the world‚Äôs climate is changing from bad to worse is unhelpful alarmism that prevents us from focusing on smart solutions."

You lose credibility when you fail to mention that climate change is often worse than the scientific experts expected. For example, the IPCC often under-estimates the effects of global warming, as opposed to exaggerating them. That runs contrary to the charge of "alarmism". Therefore, abusing the term "alarmists" also reduces your credibility:

"Climate Change Skepticism and Denial: An Introduction
[...]
A constant refrain coming from the denial campaign is that climate scientists are ‚Äúalarmists‚Äù who exaggerate the degree and threat of global warming to enhance their status, funding, and influence with policy makers. The contribution by William Freudenburg and Violetta Muselli provides an insightful empirical test of this charge and finds it to lack support."

"Reexamining Climate Change Debates: Scientific Disagreement or Scientific Certainty Argumentation Methods (SCAMs)?"
"Climate change prediction: Erring on the side of least drama?"
"Global warming estimates, media expectations, and the asymmetry of scientific challenge"



"If we want to help the world‚Äôs poor, who are the most threatened by natural disasters, it‚Äôs less about cutting carbon emissions than it is about pulling them out of poverty. The best way to see this is to look at the world‚Äôs deaths from natural disasters over time. In the Oxford University database for death rates from floods, extreme temperatures, droughts, and storms, the average in the first part of last century, was more than 130 dead every year per million people. Since then, the death rates have dropped 97 percent to a new low in the 2010s of less than 4 per million. The dramatic decline is mostly due to economic developments that help nations withstand catastrophes. If you‚Äôre rich like Florida, a major hurricane might cause plenty of damage to expensive buildings, but it kills few people and causes only a temporary dent in economic output. If a similar hurricane hits a poorer country like the Philippines or Guatemala, it kills many more people and can devastate the economy."

You lose credibility when you mislead people via faulty use of analogies. There are at least 2 distinct issues here:
1) what caused a problem; can we stop that cause?
2) how do you cope with a problem?
This roughly lines up with the distinction between mitigation (that's 1) and adaptation (that's 2).

For some natural disasters like hurricanes and earthquakes, we have trouble stopping the cause of the disaster. Thus we don't really focus on 1. We instead focus on 2, where we try to cope with the damage from the disaster. That's where wealth comes in. So, for instance, your wealth won't prevent an earthquake, but it will allow you to buy a house that can better withstand earthquakes. So wealth helps with 2.

Now, suppose we found a method to stop the cause of earthquakes. We would certainly be interested in pursuing that method. It would make no sense to object to this method by saying:
"it‚Äôs less about preventing earthquakes than it is about pulling people out of poverty".
That's misguided; you should deal with the root cause of the problem, not just rely on people's wealth helping them cope with the problem. 

We do the same thing for other issues like viral diseases; we try to deal with the root cause of the disease (that is": the virus), instead of just giving people the wealth to help cope with the problem. If we can remove the problem (by removing the problem's root cause), then people won't need to spend money on the problem and they can instead spend their money on other things. Parallel points apply for climate change; deal with the root causes of climate change, as opposed to claiming that the issue is more about helping people get wealth.

text:
SEA LEVEL: "Accelerating sea level rise" refers to a much larger trend than the blip in the data you provide. See figure 3a here (Church 2008): http://academics.eckerd.edu/instructor/hastindw/MS1410-001_FA08/handouts/2008SLRSustain.pdf and figure D here (Kopp et al 2016): http://www.pnas.org/content/113/11/E1434/F2.large.jpg

DROUGHTS: The study you provided is about drought monitoring and did not assert that droughts are less common, you merely clipped the graph and drew a trendline with no R value shown. Furthermore, droughts are not supposed to rapidly increase globally, but in dry areas. other areas will receive excess precipitation. There is no net change in moisture. https://www.epa.gov/climate-indicators/climate-change-indicators-drought

HURRICANES: Yes this is true, but only because that's a terrible way to measure hurricane severity. Consider that we may also be getting better at preparing for them, as you mention later in the video. A better way is by integrating the power dissipation of the hurricane over its lifetime. This shows an EXTREMELY high correlation with sea surface temperature and, as a result, has increased over time. see figure 1a here (Emmanuel 2005): ftp://texmex.mit.edu/pub/emanuel/PAPERS/NATURE03906.pdf

PHILIPPINES: Of course you can find an area as small as the Philippines where hurricane frequency has slightly dropped because 1) hurricane frequency is still a subject of debate and 2) the Philippines are a small area compared to the globe.

The rest is true as well, but there's no reason we can't do those things while also keeping people informed of the severity of the situation. Your rhetoric makes it seem as though it's "alarmism" that inhibits the growth of green energy sources, rather than climate change denying think-tanks that seek to confuse the issue, such as the ones funded by The Randolph Foundation: Cato Institute, FreedomWorks, the Competitive Enterprise Institute, Americans for Prosperity, and who knows what through DonorsTrust.

I can't help but notice your organization, the Copenhagen Consensus Center, is also a beneficiary.
http://conservativetransparency.org/recipient/copenhagen-consensus-center-us/

text: Cherry picking data at its finest with "gaining antarctica sea ice". Sea ice is seasonal and is often a poor measurement of climate change pace.  In actuality, the gaining of sea ice is caused by warmer temperatures as warmer air temperature can hold more moisture, which, when precipitates in antarctica, results in greater snowfall.  Note that this warmer air-more sea ice causation is only observed when temperatures rise from "far below" 0 to "just below" 0, so its not like I'm claiming that by this logic it should snow more in 50deg heat haha

text: Somewhat well done, despite it's own biases and flawed logic in a few places. Example: suggesting co2 rising despite "alarmism" (proactive education and concern on the topic) is evidence for it not being effective is disingenuous. CO2 remained rising due to the enormous global infrastructure and corporate interests that would have continued regardless of messaging taken. When short term reductions of CO2 emissions will inevitably hurt profits, expect resistance. Yes, not every worst case prediction is coming true in exactly the way some have predicted. That doesn't mean the situation is not still incredibly urgent. The most important issue to understand is the strong correlation between CO2 and global temperatures over the last 300,000 years which has been remarkably predictive. That the last decade has seen CO2 levels reach new highs far greater than any in history is a serious cause for concern. Some "alarmism" is justified when [economic game] theory would suggest individual and corporate greed will continue to push CO2 as high as it's profitable to do so without concern for environmental externalities.

text:
Bravo! Well said and very reasonable. But still based on flawed data. CO2 is not the driver of global warming. And Global Warming is actually THE solution, because we currently live in an Ice Age interglacial that's overdue to end. Let's put this in perspective. We currently have a tiny blip of warmth, on a plateau of warmth called the Holocene, with a huge valley of cold just before it. This is an Ice Age. And before it began, we had mountains of warmth that dwarf our minuscule modern warming. Life thrived during that period, because tropics were largely the same, deserts far smaller, and temperature zones went all the way to the poles. Far more life!

I like Bjorn Lomborg's approach, but he's still working with incomplete and flawed data. Global Warming made civilization possible 12,000 years ago; I'd hate to think that the inevitable cooling from the Holocene ending would lead to civilization becoming impossible. Ask yourself what made civilization possible; why was warming instrumental? When you understand that, then you will see the value of warming, and the nature of the current lies being sold.

I mostly don't agree with Prager, but this one is obviously well done. 

Still I have some sidenotes: 

- There was a research about the stagnating rise of sea level. It implicated that when ice melts, it actually takes less space than the ice itself. That's something to check in the upcoming decades. 

- The costs of green power plants (i prefer it to say it that way, marketing is part of the world ;) ) Have gone down dramatically the last decade already. If you see the progress of solar panels these days, we went 20x more efficient than in 2005! The production costs are now way lower than then.  Wind turbines are starting to get somewhere now with TW mills. The problem is still the noise and shadow, but we're going somewhere now. Green is steamrolling and we just started!

- We are now at a point that if we refinance ALL of our money invested and spent in fossil fuels (including nuclear) into green energy, we can actually be green in 2050. This and we even spare a TRILLION of Euro's with it. Of course it is not yet a card to play, but the possibility is there. More innovations in the next decade will make the grade for sure. 

Still, we are aware now some things have to change and the question is just: how? We agree on that. Let's do awesome stuff!
author: joehoe222

text:
The amount of antarctic sea ice is not an argument that global warming is slowing or not as bad as we thought. For one thing, the amount of decrease in the arctic is almost 3 times as much as the gain in the antarctic. For another thing, the growth of sea ice in the antarctic is due to cold winds blowing off the continent in the antarctic. There is no continent in the arctic. Also, there are record levels of water melting into the antarctic from the glaciers on the continent. That water is fresh water since it forms from snowfall, and thus freezes at a higher temperature than saltwater (since there are no glaciers at the arctic this isn't a factor there). Snow in the antarctic also causes increased ice formation by pushing ice underwater which protects the ice from melting (temperatures are higher closer to the surface).

Because of this last point the increased ice in the antarctic is a sign of increased warming. More snowfall is a sign of increased temperatures because warmer air holds more moisture.
author: Box Top

text:
Some thoughts...
-Copenhagen Consensus Center? Please correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't that a think tank that purely consists of economists and addresses in a kind of biased way on a economically beneficial level?
-Melting graph: Antarctic rise in ice mass doesn't seem to compensate the decline in ice mass, which sucks. Also does melting ice not have as big as an effect on the global water volume compared to a rise of temperature (1 litre of warm water has a higher volume than 1 litre of cold water).
-Rising sea levels: rate of rising sea levels isn't really an issue if the levels are still rising. The situation still sucks and its just a matter of more or less years until a lot of people will have some problems.
-Drought have decreased, but desertification is still a present threat and one that doesn't seem to go away in the coming years. So the situation still sucks.
-I'm very happy that worst and best scenario comparison was mentioned. This is important, we need to look at both scenarios and understand both of them.
-Plotting hurricane damage with an adjustment to population and wealth looks like some disgusting utilitarianism to me. Of course the hurricane damage will decrease if the population and the wealth of a nation increases. One could have adjusted the graph to the amount of kittens in the US and one would have received the same result. A plot with the occurrence of hurricanes and their damage in total numbers adjusted to inflation would have made much more sense.
-Getting people out of poverty is easier said than done. Although important, since then these people will have a higher chance to survive. But still, if we can not stop and reverse global desertification and the increase of global temperature, there will be a lot more of land that is uninhabitable. This leads to people loosing their place to live, to decrease in global stability and an increase in global poverty.
-Other energy sources: The argument that the usage of solar and wind powered energy are "expensive, feel-good measures that have as good as no effect" is kind of a silly argument. Of course they don't really have an effect if we still pollute the crap out of our planet. We're only at the start. That's about as a stupid argument as a king in the middle ages saying: "we don't need to invest in hand guns. the will have as good as no effect on winning a battle. They are just loud and heavy". By investing in these kind of energy sources we are actually doing what this video says we should do about these kind of green energy sources. Just wait a few years, things will be better.
- loved the final word. We really need to come together and talk with each other to find the best solution.

People demand protest against companies that are causing severe environmental problems for both locals and the globe, especially when they ignore simple environmental policies in the name of maximizing profits, profits don't exist without consequences. 

But your insisting is that we do precisely nothing, even when you say the climate is a problem.

Many christian fundamentalist who no surprise are anti-environment as their barbaric book of fables prescribe to subdue the earth don't think that climate is even something to even address at all, since they believe that these are the end times and that Jesus is coming back anyway before any of that matters. It seems that we are about to be bashing head to head :-D

Recycling is not a lie. It doesn't have 100 % efficiency, but it is far from what you say. If you'd need more resources (your 120 barrels of oil) to recycle than to produce from scratch, why would anyone ever recycled anything, it would be more expensive.
Recycling isn't perfect, but it is far better than just dumping old and building new.

About that "using 1.5 Earhts" It's a bit misleading. Main part of that index are CO2 emissions. According to the index, Earth has some capacity to get CO2 out of the atmosphere through photosynthesis and if we produce less CO2, than this capacity, CO2 levels won't be increasing. I don't think, this is relevant, because while living plant is scooping carbon from the atmosphere, dead plant is releasing it back again as it decomposes. Only plants that get burried really takes carbon out of the atmosphere (and in milions of years they turn into coal). So I don't think that there is a capacity for Earth to reduce CO2 levels. Well, there has to be, but it would be really miniscule. 
Notice, that this doesn't go against your arguement, it supports it by saying "the number should be actually higher"

But what what goes against your arguement "The only way to solve climate change is reduction in consumption and population" is this: cleaner technology. While it is true, that we use more natural resources this year than the last year. The rate of increase is going down as better technologies are implemented. Think is, that resource consumption is driven up mainly because of East Asia, India and South America. Those regions still have some population icrease (while Europe and North America already halted population increase) and they are getting richer and richer. With more money people consume more. Those countries are getting richer and pollute more, because they are not quite there yet to implement clean technology. Carbon footprint of Europe is in fact going down a little. India, China, Brazil, they will get there too. It will take about 50 more years and several flooded cities and several droughts before it will happen, but it most likely will. 
We don't need really to reduce our consumption and if we needed to, I don't know how to convince mass of people to do that. People don't want to give away their luxuries.
What we need is faster implementation of cleaner and cleaner technology and better recycling technology.

About population growth and hostility of environment: less and less people dies because of natural catastrophes than 50 or 100 years ago. Well that is in this very video. Technology helps us thrive in worse environment and money well being drives our fertility down.

About capitalism, it's just one of many systems of distributing wealth. I think it works quite well, but my question was: what system do you propose?
About inequalities: all through human history, one percent of population had most of the wealth. Take ancient pharaos. They own everything, even the people themselves. It's just nowadays, there is so much wealth that this inequality gets even more pronounced.
