text: 0:28 looks like the Antarctic Sea Ice is increasing slower than the Arctic Sea Ice is decreasing, implying a net loss. Hence this video is misleading. 0:45 Two papers out of how many total? Important to note a study is not necessarily¬†a¬†discovery of facts, and that climate science is a question of probability. Secondly, a 'small decline in the rate of increase' does not imply the ocean level's no longer increasing! 0:57 Again the question regarding a lone study, but more importantly, is 30 years a long enough timeframe to identify a trend? Or is this a statistical anomaly (temporary trend) as generally expected from complicated systems? 1:23 "We've gotten better at running away in time before our stuff gets destroyed!" is a very poor argument to feel at ease. At this rate I likely won't finish the video, because it seems a waste of time to watch. 1:51 This appears to be a red herring: A local change in weather does not imply globally things aren't getting worse. Moreover, looking at this graph, one can draw a flatline through it: There's no clear improvement here, either. 2:05 I agree that being overly alarmist is bad (the media is doing this now to drum up ad revenue, and likely help rich people consolidate their power), but this video is even worse by misleading less scientifically educated people into thinking there's no risk at all, that it's all a hoax -- though that's not what he literally says after each argument, it's what he implies in his speech during each argument. 2:19 It seems to me to be a question of "both/and", not "either/or": We should cut emissions to mitigate the serious risk of catastrophe, and we should help people out of poverty. People do not need fossil fuel and deforestation to leave poverty: Richer nations can help them directly into the same sustainable technologies they are currently developing for themselves. It requires more personal sacrifice, however, i.e. Americans may need to live with less material wealth as some of it is redirected temporarily to help these poorer countries into sustainable ways of living (i.e. skipping the same problematic route of development that the now-developed nations took).

text:
The history is simple. The worst instance of global warming was a paltry 10 degrees over less than 100,000 years. The current rate of global warming is on track to reach a 10 degree increase in less than a thousand years. About 1,000  times faster than the previous record.
That warming event was the Permian-Triassic boundary, where 90% of life went extinct because it couldn't adapt to the rapid change.
Sea ice is meaningless in terms of sea levels. It's already in the ocean, so it's the same water whether it's solid or liquid. The real question is what's happening to the glaciers. The glaciers of Greenland and Antarctica are melting at a rate far beyond what scientists predicted, causing massive amounts of very cold fresh water to flow into the Antarctic seas, where it freezes as more sea ice. the growth of sea ice in Antarctic is a warning, not a relief.

text:
More crap from the PragerU crap factory.

Here is the truth about Lomborg and his "work"

> Bjorn Lomborg Is Part Of The Koch Network ‚Äî And Cashing In
http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2014/06/25/3453053/koch-bjorn-lomborg-lousy-t-shirt/

> On 2nd April 2015 an Australian Consensus Centre was contracted to be established at the University of Western Australia, with Bjorn Lomborg being made an Adjunct Professor.[12] It was then discovered that this centre was being funded by the Australian Government for $4 million.[13]

> Lomborg is not a climate scientist or economist and has published little or no peer-reviewed research on environmental or climate policy. His extensive and extensively documented[2],[3] errors and misrepresentations, which are aimed at a lay audience, "follow a general pattern"[2] of minimizing the need to cut carbon emissions.

> Claims made by Lomborg in a November 2010 Op-Ed in the Washington Post[7] were subsequently debunked by the Climate Science Rapid Response Team, "a scientist-run initiative to link top climate scientists with the media".[8]

> Geoengineering research proponent Ken Caldeira has said "the vision of Lomborg‚Äôs Climate Consensus is ‚Äúa dystopic world out of a science fiction story... Geoengineering is not an alternative to carbon emissions reductions ... If emissions keep going up and up, and you use geoengineering as a way to deal with it, it‚Äôs pretty clear the endgame of that process is pretty ugly.‚Äù"[9].

> The extensive and uncritical acceptance of Lomborg's claims prompted a reaction from the scientific community. In January 2002 Scientific American's editor, John Rennie, wrote the preface to a ten page critique written by four specialists. Rennie commented that "the errors described here, however, show that in its purpose of describing the real state of the world, the book is a failure". [25]

> The late Dr. Stephen Schneider, professor in the Department of Biological Sciences and Senior Fellow at the Institute for International Studies at Stanford University, criticised Lomborg for inaccurately portraying the work of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and misrepresenting the Kyoto Protocol. (Schneider is also editor of Climate Change and lead author of several of the IPCC chapters and the IPCC guidance paper on uncertainties).

> Dr. Schneider also writes "most scientists I know working on these problems are outraged by Lomborg's work and consider it to be faulty and misrepresentative of their published views. In addition to referencing a biased sample of literature that wasn't nearly broad enough, Lomborg used quotes out of context and proved numerous times that he did not fully understand the science behind climate change"[26]

http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php/Bjorn_Lomborg

"CO2 had a much higher concentration than we have now! They also indicate that Climate Change need not be "man made"" - That was complete fallacy. Let me give you an example everyone can agree with. "Increasing solar activity can rise the temperature. But if solar activity is falling, then why would you blame it for rising temperatures?" One outcome can have multible causes. So what if CO2 had higher consentration in the past? Nobody has argued otherwise. The question is what caused those conditions? And what is causing this condition now?
There is no proof. Well ofcourse not if you ignore everything scientists want to tell you. Just say they lie and you support your own claims huh? It doesn't work that way.
author: Armoured Challenger

text: ¬†@Armoured Challenger¬† ...but my thinking is based in science!  Just because people can be bought through grants that require that man made climate change be the result (as many of your scientist are), no one is buying me!  I can look at things with no bias!  When doing an experiment, you try to minimize variables!  To minimize variables in climate change, you would have to be able to control the sun's output and make it stable.  You would also have to eliminate all sources of CO2 other than man made!  Then you could check with reasonable certainty that what man is doing is exactly the cause for man made climate change!  ...but you can't do that!  You can't stop all forest fires...stop all animal life from breathing...control all CO2 absorption by bacteria and plant life...you just can't control everything that needs to be controlled to get accurate data!!  Therefore, you cannot prove that climate change is indeed man made!  I see a populace that is basically stupid (thanks to the politicization of public education) and I see people pushing an agenda to take control of industry and people!  You may think that's good, but I think it's a usurpation of our Right to Freedom!  If you want to believe in the leftist religion of man made climate change, feel free!  I choose to not be swayed by consensus!  Consensus by definition is not science!!!  Consensus is simply mob rule!  For every statistic you present to support, I can present a statistic to counter.
author: Robert Green

text: ¬†@*****¬† It's not stupid!  Can you identify who and what caused Death Valley to recently go to 130 degrees F?  "Well," you say, "it's obvious that man made climate change resulted in such a high temperature!"  Then I ask, "...but what about in 1913 when it was 134 degrees F?  Where was the man made climate change in 1913?"  The climate is constantly changing!!!  No one will ever prove if it's man made or not!  Scientists who rely on grants will fudge the data whatever way they need to to get next year's grant money!!!  ALWAYS follow the money!!!  The biggest problem we have is instantaneous communications!!!  Everything that is supposedly wrong with the environment now has parallels in the past!  People just didn't hear about them!!!  People suffer from information overload and it's easy to sway people who just trust what supposed experts tell them!!!  Climate Change is a religion of the Left!!!  Believe it if you must, but I don't!  I think it's a false religion!!!  ...and I'll fight against it for as long as I can!  Mostly because it's wrong and can't be proven!!!

Yes, bought. Lets follow the money, alright! The money for research comes from research grants. Well done. You proved precisely dick. Does it include possibility that scientists may cheat? Yes. NASA is funded by the government but that doesn't mean that Saturn is a leftist conspiracy.

I kind of smiled a little bit when you said that you can look stuff without bias. It was generally funny.

To minimize variables in data you have to choose large enough time periods to average out, to remove small term cyclic or non variations. That's why individual years have no meaning, "oh this year was colder than the previous so the Earth is cooling." No, it's not like that. You average these out and only major long term forcings are left. Now it's a lot easier to deal with less variables.
That way you don't have to account for every single thing or have perfect stability and you have accurate data (just over longer time period).

Have you ever wondered. Do these people know something I don't? Listen to a scientists and go say to their faces that they are wrong. Explain your point of view. I'm sure you will be unpleasantly suprised.

text: Explain how to supposedly prevent climate change. Use numbers in your answer.
author: hitssquad

text:
+hitssquad I'm not that guy, but I'll give it a go. 
Reduce carbon emissions globally by 2% per year for 40 years, and we will have reduced the effect of climate change by about half of what it would be if trends continue. That is what we would have to do in order to keep the global temperature increase to less than what is considered "disastrous" (6 degree farenheit increase).
In the US we can spend $25 billion per year (less than we spend on oil subsidies) building renewable energy plants to replace our fossil fuel-powered ones. In 40 years we would have replaced all of it with "clean" energy, just like germany. And speaking off germany, did you know that germans don't pay for electricity? Well they pay for maintenance in their taxes, but the plants produce more energy than they can use, so germans get paid to use electricity. 
This plan doesn't phase out gas-powered cars or the oil used in plastics, but it takes care of the largest source of carbon emissions.

author: Richard Lock

text:
By volume, dry air contains 78.09% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen,[1] 0.93% argon, 0.039% carbon dioxide, and small amounts of other gases. Air also contains a variable amount of water vapor, on average around 1% at sea level, and 0.4% over the entire atmosphere. Air content and atmospheric pressure vary at different layers, and air suitable for use in photosynthesis by terrestrial plants and breathing of terrestrial animals is found only in Earth's troposphere and in artificial atmospheres.

The atmosphere has a mass of about 5.15√ó1018 kg,[2] three quarters of which is within about 11 km (6.8 mi; 36,000 ft) of the surface. The atmosphere becomes thinner and thinner with increasing altitude, with no definite boundary between the atmosphere and outer space. The K√°rm√°n line, at 100 km (62 mi), or 1.57% of Earth's radius, is often used as the border between the atmosphere and outer space. Atmospheric effects become noticeable during atmospheric reentry of spacecraft at an altitude of around 120 km (75 mi). Several layers can be distinguished in the atmosphere, based on characteristics such as temperature and composition.

author: Benji De Aula

text:
¬†@Benji Deaula¬† As you said, drawing Salt Water into a once through style Nuclear power plant is tedious, high maintenance costs. Not exactly cheap renewable energy.

Now that being said. You stated you could not think of anything else that was a negative on Nuclear power plants. I did not want to go to deep into detail as to why drawing such massive amounts of water from the eco system... running it through super heated steam pipes.... then returning that hot water back into lakes / streams / oceans.... but I guess I have to now.

1. Organisms do not like super heated steam temperatures. Bacteria? Algae? Natural eco system of the lake / stream / ocean? Ya.... tends to set thinks all out of wack when you super heat their water and return it to them. Any measure you put into place to cool the returning water still doesn't change the fact that you flash boiled purified the water coming in. (this style nuclear power system is called the once through system in cooling)

2. Wet-recirculating or closed-loop Nuclear cooling system. You run into the same problems as #1...¬†you are still consuming large amounts of water.... flash boiling it on super heated steam pipes.... and after 2-3 cycles of being purified sending it back into the eco system. Pretty much, purchase a 50 gallon fresh water fish aquarium.... get your nitrogen cycle started.... then after you have a thriving eco system... drain 80% of that water out... and fill it back up... every single day... Tell me how your fish are doing after a month.

3. Dry-Cooling nuclear cooling systems. Very inefficient... super expensive... but hey... you save the eco system.
author: ganthore

text: ¬†@ganthore¬† The Diablo Canyon plant desalinates the seawater before using it for cooling. Before the water is returned to the sea, the salt is added back. It isn't expensive.
author: hitssquad

text: ¬†@hitssquad¬† Exactly, but... This brings an interesting possibility. Sea levels are rising, yes? So why instead of re-salinating the water, why not, after it has been evaporated and turning the turbines, that water is then used for the public water supply? It would certainly help this drought of ours.
author: Benji De Aula

text:
¬†@hitssquad¬† I understand that the Diablo Canyon Plant is a fine piece of engineering... however it is not without it's negative effects.

1. It is more expensive that a regular fresh water plant (but not by much)

2. It was built on the Shoreline fault line... aka Earthquake headquarters (they didn't realize it at the time of construction... but it is California... so how could they not know?)

3. California has already signed a law to close down the powerplant in 2025. Hippies seem to hate anything that is not solar / wind power

4. Only half of the saltwater poured into the plant is desalinized. The other half becomes heavy concentrated Brine... which is incredibly deadly to salt water creatures in the ocean. (yes it dilutes back to normal relatively quickly... but the harm is done).

5. You are still killing whatever organisms are in the water you are taking in to begin with.

Now do not mistake me pointing out the environmental dangers of things like nuclear energy with not wanting it at all. I want oil / coal / nuclear / fracking to continue. I was simply responding to the OP of this comment thread of him believing there was no negatives to nuclear power... There are plenty of negatives.

text:
There is often this assumption that Climate Change is a bad thing. Why is this assumption made? Because of the increased droughts, rising sea levels or storms? What is usually not appreciated is that while some areas of the world are certainly going to change for the worse, some might change for the better. For example, if the temperature were to rise in places like Canada or Siberia, millions upon millions of acres of tundra may thaw out and become habitable. 

Couldn't the tundra thawing out in these places create opportunities for new farm land that could help to feed millions or lift many out of poverty? The real truth is that no one has the ability to say for sure whether climate change will be a net good or bad. How do you weigh rising sea levels in Florida vs. the thawing out of Canada? I suggest we just let Nature take it's natural course and adapt as best we can to changing circumstances. It'll be cheaper and more effective.

text:
First of all, amazing video! 

I live in Ontario, Canada and we have a significant problem of the government over-exaggerating the issue of climate change and global warming, so much that it's almost brainwashing. TV channels are always filled with one-sided government-funded global warming commercials that provide no objectivity whatsoever, and are just sometimes misleading. These commercials exaggerate the magnitude of global warming. They just help to promote the government in power and to improve its public image. 

Some of you may know that Ontario is the largest sub-nation debtor in the world due to rampant misspending and corruption in the provincial government. The Liberal Party of Ontario has been accepting many "political donations" from lots of green-energy companies, and in return the government "rewards" these companies subsidies. The provincial police has investigated and found that Ontario's green-energy sector is filled with corruption. The government subsides to wind power have gone miserably wrong, as these corrupt companies do not build good and reliable wind turbines. Taxpayer money is just wasted on giving subsidies to companies that bribed the government and these companies poorly construct wind turbines. 

Ontario's education system is also flawed as it educates (kind of brainwashes actually) youth so much about that global warming is a massive issue, that it only provides a one-sided perspective, leading youth to to think that global warming is very severe. Every year we learn about climate change and global warming; so much that I don't know why we're still learning about it.

I'm not saying that climate change or global warming is fake, I'm saying that we should stop exaggerating the issue, try to focus on the truth, and that politicians should stop taking advantage of this to get votes and bribes.

author: Lucas Sze

text:
¬†@Lucas Sze¬† > America colludes with big businesses all the time, we are just more subtle and restricted.

Yes, much more subtle and limited in extent. It's still a big problem but nothing like China, thankfully. 

I'm Libertarian. I want less regulations on businesses and a smaller government in general. Regulations bring us closer to China, not further away, because it is through regulations that the corruption is linked between big business and big government. Big business on its own is not a threat at all.
author: UnknownXV

text:
¬†@UnknownXV¬† Of course big businesses are not inherently evil, but many big businesses leverage their power to bribe congressmen to block regulations.

Of course, many congressmen are bribed to create regulations to crush small businesses and other competition.

There is no easy answer to this topic, since either way these can be leveraged to hurt businesses in general.
author: Lucas Sze

text:
¬†@Lucas Sze¬† Yup, but more often they want more regulations because they can cope with them easily, but their competition cannot. 

The only answer is a smaller government, so big business has nothing to leverage from the government.
author: UnknownXV

text:
¬†@UnknownXV¬† I have to say, I think libertarians are the only party who I think truly want small government. Republicans want to get into people's private lives, while Democrats want to pass and enforce regulation after regulation.

I slightly disagree that we need a smaller government, because we do need things like the ability to take down monopolies and preventing big businesses from taking down their competition as easily. Other than that, I agree with you.
author: Lucas Sze

text:
¬†@Lucas Sze¬† Absolutely. We share half from the left and half from the right, at least in the good bits they say (rarely do they follow through when elected).

Monopolies aren't a big threat. If one forms, big deal. Don't buy their products or services if they suck. Eventually other companies will jump in if they see a market opportunity. And no, I don't just mean small startups, I mean established companies from unrelated or differing markets. The best example of this is Google battling in the ISP market now with Google Fiber. 

What we need is less government regulation so more competition happens organically.
author: UnknownXV

text: It is called, "presenting multiple viewpoints." Something TYT does not do.
author: gcHK47

text:
¬†@gcHK47¬† TYT is the trashiest, biased, most misleading popular liberal "news" site on youtube.

Even when I agree with them, their arguments are mostly based on technicalities and misleading comments made by no name politicians.

In many instances, I do agree with their main points, but the way they go about attempting to convince people is disgusting.

Also, there is a difference between presenting multiple viewpoints and putting up an idiot to blabber about misleading facts. Bill O'Reilly, when not playing his over the top character on FOX, does a great job of presenting a viewpoint opposite to my own. I may disagree with him, but I understand where he is coming from. It's with intelligent people that one can have a nuanced conversation about complex issues
author: Lucas Sze

text:
¬†@UnknownXV¬† There are some things that people cannot live without, and therefore are forced to comply with the exorbitantly high prices that come with a monopoly.

Oil, for instance, is an essential part of almost all forms of transportation, so it doesn't matter how high the prices are. People have to buy it.

Medicine for life threatening illnesses also must be bought no matter what, since if the consumer doesn't, they will die.

Businesses know this. They corner a small section of the medicine market and jack up the prices. Consumers with chronic diseases or life threatening illnesses will have to buy them and bear the financial strain they impose, because they have no choice.

Even if businesses decide not to jack up the prices, their brand recognition will become so powerful that it becomes almost impossible to break into the market. The company with the monopoly can just sit on its current products and make money. Creativity and innovation will stagnate.

So yes, monopolies are, in almost all situations, at least somewhat bad for the economy.

The problem is Congress' ability to employ regulations to take down monopolies. A lot of the times they just end up stamping out any hope of ANY competitors rising up against the monopoly, either because they are sponsored by the business, or they lack understanding of the economy.

There is no easy answer to this dilemma we have. Such is the burden of capitalism and shitty congressmen.
author: Lucas Sze

text:
¬†@Lucas Sze¬† The only things people can't live without are food and water, which will never be a monopoly. 

People do not have to buy oil. There are alternative sources of energy, they just aren't efficient relative to oil at the moment. If the costs for oil increase a lot, then the alternatives become more worthwhile. 

Medicine is indeed important, and the best way to reduce the possibility of a monopoly there is removing government barrier to entry. Due to the FDA, it can take a decade and hundreds of millions of dollars to develop  a new drug. This ensures that only those already established through the bureaucratic hoops can compete. 

It's never impossible to break into a market. It just takes someone with the will to do so, and a brilliant idea. As far as resources go, often for established monopolies it'll take an established company to do it. The best example is Google with ISPs. They're destroying them effortlessly. Google Fiber would be in most cities by now if not for government regulations. 

Monopolies aren't a good thing, my point was simply that they aren't some monstrous threat that will end civilization like people treat them. They are at most a slight negative, and especially in a market environment with few to no government barrier to entry, it'll be almost impossible to become a monopoly. And even if you somehow do, that won't last for long at all. Especially if you become complacent in your position.

¬†@Tastypie¬†
¬†Until the fusion reactor is developed, Molten Salt Fission reactors will remain the safest, cleanest form of nuclear energy. Terrestrial Energy just got a grant to build one. No risk of meltdown. It's as safe as a Fusion reactor and the science was researched in the 60's. It consumes the vast majority of it's fuel (fission fuel that is unconsumed makes up the majority of the nuclear waste) and it can be made modular, unlike the very bulky fusion reactors we are designing now.

May I just say, as a general note to the people here, Nuclear Reactors don't create Earthquakes, George. Fukashima was also a 30 year old design that took an Earthquake that disabled the electrical pumps for the cooling pools. Then the Diesel engines kicked in to take up the slack. They were in the basement, designed to take an Earthquake. Then the tsunami hit and drowned them. The Molten Salt Reactor solves both of those problems because the fuel is already a liquid, and in the event of catastrophic power failure, it drains into tanks that disperse the fuel and scram the reactor. When the Capital cost of Fusion Reactors is lower than the Capital cost of fission reactors... call me.

author: Richard Roberson

text:
I agree. I think we should switch to a less harmful reactor (like Thorium) for the time being, while slowly developing better fusion technology. So far, the two innovations made on fusion both cannot explode (in a nuclear fireball) or cause major damage to the environment, because if the power breaks and the safeties fail, the entire thing will just turn off. Normally in a nuclear fission plant, that would be very dangerous, but in the innovations, the fuel is forced into a coil by supercooled magnets, and if they fail, the plasma would expand and cool, and would not be able to explode in a giant fireball, and because of the cooler temperatures they cannot fuse. It only uses a few grams of tritium or helium-3 at a time, so a leak would be quickly diluted and essentially no problems would really arise.

The only problem with this is the expense. So if we could lower the cost somehow in the future, this would be some of the best clean energy made by mankind.

text:
There are several problems with having a reactor underground.

First is the cost of operation. In order to adequetly cool a plant the underground, you'd have to have cooling towers that extended all the way to the surface, plus got extra costs of getting manpower and suplies in and out of the underground facility.

Second thing to consider is the water table. Any plant built underground would likely be under the local water table and any leakage of radiation would get into the groundwater.

Third, safety and recuse operations would be much more complicated having only one or two access points,,

text: You can't prove a negative, but the claim that humans are a primary driving factor in climate change usually cites the correlation of growing CO2 concentrations with global temperatures as evidence.  The fact that scientists have been unable to produce reliable models means that, at the very least, we do not know enough about our impact to determine whether Miami should be underwater.  It follows that, if we can't accurately predict whether entire cities will be submerged, then we don't understand our impact well enough to proclaim that we are the driving factor with certainty.

text:
Let's not beat around the rapidly melting iceberg here.
Climate change is happening and we're causing it. The evidence is overwhelming.
Scientists usually reserve this level of agreement for claims like, "Earth
is a planet" or "air is real". Yet here we are. The climate
change ship has left the dock, yet lots of people on shore are still debating
whether boats can actually float. But maybe you're a person that trusts and
accepts what climate scientists are telling us. It's just... sometimes it's
hard to explain why. I mean, we've all been there.

‚ÄúI mean, I care about the environment. I figure with the
polar bears and everything. We might as well try electric cars. What do we have
to lose?‚Äù And then they go "caps lock serious" saying they have proof
that climate change is a hoax perpetuated by scientists paid off by the
"Polar Bear Lobby" as part of a plan to install Al Gore's supreme
world polar bear emperor. Wake up 'sheeple!'

To keep that from happening, we put together this handy
reference: The Science of Climate Change in 24 Easy Steps. (1) The sun is the
source of warmth on earth. So, thanks for that, sun. Ice and clouds reflect
some of its light away, but the rest is absorbed by land and water and
re-emitted as heat. Some of that heat escapes to space and some is held in by
the Atmospheric Greenhouse Effect. (2) The insulating effect of earth's
Greenhouse Gases are the reason the life exists as we know it, but (3) human
activities have increased the concentration of one of them, carbon dioxide, 40%
since the Industrial Revolution (1790).

(4) We know the sun's output is varied during history, but
since the 1970s, the period when global temperatures increased the fastest,
temperature and solar activity have moved in opposite directions. (5) If the
sun was to blame, it would cook the upper and lower layers of the atmosphere
together. Instead, we only see warming in the lower layers. The same place that
human greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide are piling up. (6) Since 1870, with
fossil fuels, cement production, and land-use combined, humans have put about
2,000 gigatons of CO2 into the atmosphere. That's two million million tons. And
about 40% has stayed there.

(7) Studying gases trapped in ice cores has let us see what
earth's atmosphere was like in the past. At more than 400 parts per million,
today's carbon dioxide levels are the highest they've been for almost a million
years (190ppm - 800,000 years ago). That's before humans even existed. Totally
uncharted territory for us. (8) More carbon dioxide in the atmosphere means
average temperatures across the globe are increasing, and fast. Right now,
earth is warming about 10 times faster than at the end of an ice age (today is
+0.6C, end of ice age is +0.06C per 100 year span).

Okay so, CO2 is increasing. How do we know it's our fault?
The best evidence comes from looking at what isotopes or different kinds of
carbon are in the atmosphere. (9) Fossil fuels come from mainly old plants.
Plants prefer to use the lighter isotope, carbon 12, over the heavier, carbon
13. So, they contain a higher ratio of 12 to 13 than the atmosphere does. When
more fossil fuels get burned, the percentage of carbon 12 in the atmosphere
should go up, and that's exactly what we see. (10) And it's not because of
volcanic activity. Volcanoes only emit about 1% as much CO2 as we do. (11) Normally,
that CO2 is balanced and exchanged between the atmosphere of plants and
animals, but eliminating carbon sinks has released centuries worth in just a
few years.

(12) Other greenhouse gases are also increasing, like methane
from farm animals and natural gas processing or nitrous oxide from fertilizers.
(13) If we run simulations just using natural causes of Climate Change, they
predict no change or even cooling in the 20th century, and that is not what's
happening. (14) It's still going to get cold in some places, but in the 2000s
there were twice as many record highs as record lows, and each of the past
three decades has been warmer than any other decade since we started measuring
in 1850 (source: Royal Society / US National Academy of Sciences). 

(15) Since 1900, actual temperatures around the world have
increased almost a full degree and most of that has happened since the 1970s.
(16) Looking at data from tree rings and ice cores, the past 30 years is
probably the warmest in eight centuries. Of course, not every place on earth
warms equally. (17) Oceans cover more than 70% of earth and they absorb more
than 90% of the heat added to the planet. Naturally, that's where we see the
most extreme changes.

(18) Around the world, oceans are rising 1/10‚Äù per year, and
they're up 8 inches since 1901. (19) This is because water expands as it warms,
and (20) when ice sheets melt in Greenland and Antarctica, water that's
normally on frozen land gets put in the ocean. (21) The oceans are earth's
largest carbon sink. As more CO2 enters the atmosphere, more of it dissolves in
the ocean, which makes the water more acidic (surface ocean pH from 9.0 to
8.08, and surface ocean CO2 from 323 to 362 ppm between 1990 and
2014). This doesn't mean the ocean's will be made of acid, (22) but animals
with calcium shells are super sensitive to pH. We're on course for the oceans
to hit pH 7.8 in a hundred years, which could wipe out 1/3 of species in the
ocean.

(23) We also know that levels of summer sea ice in the Artic
have decreased 40% since 1978. They might the lowest levels in 1400 years. (24)
That white sea ice usually reflects the sun's energy back into the atmosphere,
but the dark ocean is soaking it up like a black shirt on a sunny day, which
feeds the cycle forward.

If CO2 emissions continue on their current trends, earth is
on course to be two and a half to five degrees C warmer. The oceans could be up
to a meter higher by the end of this century. Is that a big deal? Yeah! It's
the biggest deal. This is by far the greatest issue facing our species. The
last time the earth averaged a few degrees colder, most of North America was
covered in a mile thick sheet of ice. That many degrees warmer, we're gonna
have a bad time!

So, now you're armed with the facts. Why we know climate
change is happening and why we're causing it. Please, share this information
with the people you know, and then let me know: Did it change any minds? Did it
change your mind? Are facts enough? If not, then why do so many people continue
to not believe in climate science?

+Ken Lelon, good points. Some of us merely care about the planet, but have incomplete data. Some of us have big egos and can't learn anything new. But perhaps the best way is to ask probing questions to get people thinking.

I used to support Al Gore's viewpoint, but then did some digging of my own and found it full of holes.

We live in an Ice Age interglacial that's overdue to end. It could set new records for interglacial duration, or it could already be winding down, headed for the next glacial period. No one knows. One thing people don't understand is that Global Warming made civilization possible 12,000 years ago. It was relatively impossible before that because the conditions were so deadly and restrictive. When claims are made that Global Warming will lead to more droughts and deserts, they are huge lies. Deserts shrank at the start of the Holocene. Rain became abundant, making agriculture possible.

Global cooling (ending the Holocene) could reverse that.

text:
¬†@Rod Martin, Jr.¬†

You believe that the earth is cooling, yet provided no evidence. Bummer, dude‚Ä¶

Wait, maybe you just don't understand how to do science! Here, I'll show you...

Here's my belief: The scientific evidence for human-caused rapid-warming of the global climate system is unequivocal.
¬†
Here‚Äôs my evidence:

Sea level rise - Global sea level rose about 17 centimeters (6.7 inches) in the last century. The rate in the last decade, however, is nearly double that of the last century [1].

Global temperature rise - All three major global surface temperature reconstructions show that Earth has warmed since 1880 [2]. Most of this warming has occurred since the 1970s, with the 20 warmest years having occurred since 1981 and with all 10 of the warmest years occurring in the past 12 years [3]. Even though the 2000s witnessed a solar output decline resulting in an unusually deep solar minimum in 2007-2009, surface temperatures continue to increase [4].

Warming oceans - The oceans have absorbed much of this increased heat, with the top 700 meters (about 2,300 feet) of ocean showing warming of 0.302 degrees Fahrenheit since 1969 [5].

Shrinking ice sheets - The Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have decreased in mass. Data from NASA's Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment show Greenland lost 150 to 250 cubic kilometers (36 to 60 cubic miles) of ice per year between 2002 and 2006, while Antarctica lost about 152 cubic kilometers (36 cubic miles) of ice between 2002 and 2005.

Declining Arctic sea ice - Both the extent and thickness of Arctic sea ice has declined rapidly over the last several decades [6].
Glacial retreat - Glaciers are retreating almost everywhere around the world ‚Äî including in the Alps, Himalayas, Andes, Rockies, Alaska and Africa [7].

Extreme events - The number of record high temperature events in the United States has been increasing, while the number of record low temperature events has been decreasing, since 1950. The U.S. has also witnessed increasing numbers of intense rainfall events [8].

Ocean acidification - Since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, the acidity of surface ocean waters has increased by about 30 percent [9,10]. This increase is the result of humans emitting more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere and hence more being absorbed into the oceans. The amount of carbon dioxide absorbed by the upper layer of the oceans is increasing by about 2 billion tons per year [11,12].

Decreased snow cover - Satellite observations reveal that the amount of spring snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere has decreased over the past five decades and that the snow is melting earlier [13].

References

text:
¬†@UnknownXV¬† "What is your point in even mentioning these things, if you're implying nothing from them?"

You brought them up, I was just "answering" the video, on the fact that bringing US data does not prove the entire world goes that way, simple as that.

"There's a 65.9% consensus that human kind is responsible for 50% or more of the warming since 1960s due to our release of greenhouse gases"

Source? I do not think you mean that there is an official percentage of "Scientists believing in this" right, every survey has different results. Which one is yours?


"Dennis Bray and Hans von Storch conducted a survey in August 2008 of 2058 climate scientists from 34 different countries.[121] A web link with a unique identifier was given to each respondent to eliminate multiple responses. A total of 373 responses were received giving an overall response rate of 18.2%. No paper on climate change consensus based on this survey has been published yet (February 2010), but one on another subject has been published based on the survey.[122]

The survey was composed of 76 questions split into a number of sections. There were sections on the demographics of the respondents, their assessment of the state of climate science, how good the science is, climate change impacts, adaptation and mitigation, their opinion of the IPCC, and how well climate science was being communicated to the public. Most of the answers were on a scale from 1 to 7 from 'not at all' to 'very much'.

To the question "How convinced are you that climate change, whether natural or anthropogenic, is occurring now?", 67.1% said they very much agreed, 26.7% agreed to some large extent, 6.2% said to they agreed to some small extent (2‚Äì4), none said they did not agree at all. To the question "How convinced are you that most of recent or near future climate change is, or will be, a result of anthropogenic causes?" the responses were 34.6% very much agree, 48.9% agreeing to a large extent, 15.1% to a small extent, and 1.35% not agreeing at all.

A poll performed by Peter Doran and Maggie Kendall Zimmerman at University of Illinois at Chicago received replies from 3,146 of the 10,257 polled Earth scientists. Results were analyzed globally and by specialization. 76 out of 79 climatologists who "listed climate science as their area of expertise and who also have published more than 50% of their recent peer-reviewed papers on the subject of climate change" believed that mean global temperatures had risen compared to pre-1800s levels. Seventy-five of 77 believed that human activity is a significant factor in changing mean global temperatures. Among all respondents, 90% agreed that temperatures have risen compared to pre-1800 levels, and 82% agreed that humans significantly influence the global temperature. Economic geologists and meteorologists were among the biggest doubters, with only 47 percent and 64 percent, respectively, believing in significant human involvement"



"How many of those 65.9% believe the effects of this warming are highly or even moderately negative?"

Assuming your percentage is the correct one (I highly suspect that is not the case seeming that many other surveys the percentages are much more inclined to the "Yes" part.


"That is less clear, but we're likely not even looking at a 50% consensus that climate change is significantly or even moderately negative."


Likely? Assumptions much I see.
Again.

text:
Mortebianca You're astonishing, you know that? Here we have a highly educated, experienced, and universally respected authority who is a leading expert in the field of climate studies. This man is literally a professional at studying Earth's climate by using the scientific method to reach his conclusions. Yet somehow you, a layman with none of his knowledge or experience, but an excess of ideology and free time, have the temerity to say he's the one who is wrong and you're the one who is right? And you've elected to do so simply because his cold hard facts don't align with the posturing narrative of the political ideology you choose to identify with. A narrative delivered by non-experts during elections whose field is politics instead of science, I might add. What you're doing is no different than a stubborn child sticking his fingers in his ears and repeating aloud, "I can't hear you! I can't hear you!" when he's confronted with the possibility of being wrong.

There is a term for this type of behavior: pathological. You are being pathological. You've chosen to close your mind to other arguments based on scientifically determined results simply because you've been told to do so by other smug, insincere people who actually don't know what the hell they're talking about, but who love to preen before the cameras and public as being the smartest, most cultured people in the room. Furthermore, had you actually paid attention to this video you would've heard him say that climate change is real, and is a legitimate concern facing humanity, but that the current methods being used to combat it are ineffective and wasteful. 

I honestly can not believe you have the audacity to assume you know more about this subject than the expert here does simply because his findings are not consistent with one of the planks in the platform of the party you vote for. Wow... As I stated previously, You. Are. Astonishing.

text:
¬†@Harrison Pike¬†
If you're not Left-wing (I didn't write "liberal" since they're not really synonyms), then it's probably not a good idea to use their arguments.¬† I notice that they frequently quote out of context or incompletely when the actual quotes tend to be more nuanced.

Much of California is a desert, so of course the natural climate is going to be more prone to drought.¬† California also has the largest population of all the 50 states, and that population uses a lot of water.¬† California also takes in more immigrants than other states, which exacerbates it further.

So what do the people running the state do?¬† They encourage more immigration, they cordon off a large section of fresh water sources to protect a fish that could also survive in hatcheries and also exists elsewhere in an area that is not endangered, and they fail to invest in desalinization plants but put money in a train that few will ever use.¬† It's not rocket science to figure out what the solution is.

1.  Natural Gas = $0.64
2.  Coal = $0.64
3.  Hydro-electric = $0.84
4.  Nuclear = $3.14
5.  Geothermal = $12.85
6.  Wind = $56.29
7.  Solar = $775.64

First it keeps them out of trouble.  When a teenager is working after school he/she is not hanging out with losers and getting into trouble with drugs, alcohol, sex, and general mischief.

Secondly, when a teenager works after school and during summer, it teaches them how to show up to work on time, how to behave around customers, and it also provides them the ability to learn what they want or don't want to do in life.

Thirdly, it helps teach the teenager the value of a dollar.  Many teenagers think that Socialism is wonderful because they don't understand how difficult it is for the average person to pay 42% of their earnings in taxation.

But they had a policy if I wanted to buy something that was high dollar then I could work and buy it myself.  They would provide me with the basics like food and regular shoes, but if I wanted something extra or special, then I had to work for it.

When I grew up during the 80s and 90s, I worked during summers and I bought my own mountain bike, high dollar shoes, and a used car.

For successful people, work and education do not stop at 5 pm and 3 pm.  Work and education starts when you wake up in the morning at 7 am and ends at 10 pm when you go to bed.

Most of the time after about 10 or 20 years of busting your ass from 7 am to 10 pm, you are able to pull yourself out of poverty and join the middle to upper middle class and have plenty of disposable income.

The study referenced on Forbes has been pushed by the hearthland institute, a known fake think tank known to have been funded by the tobacco industry to sow doubt about the negative health impacts of smoking throughout the second half of the last century. It is not a very far off conclusion that the money they are getting from the fossile fuels industry right now is not for independent research but for an INTENTIONAL MISINFORMATION CAMPAIGN.

And people like you, who seem to already have an opinion BEFORE they had invested enough time and dedication to prevent deception and biases just google for studies to validate themselves and the people you convince are falling victim to fake papers like this one.
Take a step back and ask yourself whether you should not be more critical of your own point of view - this is the method that makes real science and educated opinions.

But if people really said in the 70s and the 80s that we would have a drastic rise in temperatures much higher than we experienced or similiar things that didn't yet happen - yes, they have been wrong. My assertion is that the popular narrative vis-a-vis global warming is itself misinformation. There is plenty out there, including on YouTube, showing this to be so. If you don't wish to have a look, that's fine, but until you do it's probably pointless to jump on those who are skeptics. It is not radical, nor ignorant to be skeptic on this issue whatsoever, and if you did a bit of digging, you'd find that to be true, even if you still disagreed overall.

author: Theodor K

text:
+Frances Haypenny

"Irrespective of the science, the real science not the computer models,"

It seems that, like most AGW denialists on the right, you misunderstand how models (including computer models) are used in "real science". This leads to you lashing out against models. That won't work, since models are crucial to "real science". Models are how you generate hypotheses, make evidence-based predictions for future events, explain how things work and why they happen, etc.

For example, scientists have developed models for orbital mechanics. They've figured out which models work best (for example: they tested the models against experimental data), and they then use the models to predict the motion of satellites. Without these models, scientists couldn't make predictions about the future motion of satellites, and GPS-based technology would fail. Similarly, doctors and medical scientists develop models for how a drug works, how the drug causes the observed side-effects, etc. They then figure out which models work best (for example: they test the models against data generates in clinical trials, in vitro experiments, in vivo non-human animal studies, etc.), and they then use these models to predict whether the drug will work for a given patient.

So if you really think that "real science" doesn't use computer models, then have fun rejecting medicine, astronomy, physics, etc. as not being "real science".



"The arctic isn't melting, it's getting colder."

You're amazingly misinformed. Arctic sea ice is melting. Also, Arctic land ice is melting, contributing to sea level rise. This melt results from global warming:

"Recent Arctic amplification and extreme mid-latitude weather
[...]
The rapid Arctic warming has contributed to dramatic melting of Arctic sea ice and spring snow cover, at a pace greater than that simulated by climate models."

"Global Sea Ice Coverage from Satellite Data: Annual Cycle and 35-Yr Trends"
"Revisiting the contemporary sea-level budget on global and regional scales"
"Recent contributions of glaciers and ice caps to sea level rise"



"Second, 'Mother Jones' is a left wing-nut publication."
"The planet temperature hasn't risen for two decades."
"Since you will undoubtedly belittle any source I provide, why not just google something like 'no warming for twenty years' and choose a source you like."

Or you could read reputable scientific sources, like peer-reviewed scientific papers. That way, you don't have to rely on nonsense you read in denialist blogs, the conservative "wing-nut" press (to borrow your term), etc. That's what scientifically-informed people do for any scientific topic they look at, including climatology.

Anyway, there's been global warming over the past couple of decades, as observed in ocean warming, surface temperature warming, and warming of the upper atmosphere:

Atmospheric warming: 
"Sensitivity of Satellite-Derived Tropospheric Temperature Trends to the Diurnal Cycle Adjustment"
"Assessing atmospheric temperature data sets for climate studies"
"Comparing tropospheric warming in climate models and satellite data"

Surface warming: 
"Global Temperature in 2015" http://mahb.stanford.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/20160120_Temperature2015.pdf
"On the definition and identifiability of the alleged ‚Äúhiatus‚Äù in global warming"

Surface warming / ocean warming: 
"Possible artifacts of data biases in the recent global surface warming hiatus"

Ocean warming: 
"A review of global ocean temperature observations: Implications for ocean heat content estimates and climate change"
"Recent hiatus caused by decadal shift in Indo-Pacific heating"


This has led to many scientists saying that there's been no "pause" or "hiatus" in global warming:

"Has there been a hiatus?"
"Debunking the climate hiatus"
"Change points of global temperature"


Michael Mann himself feels uncomfortable with the term "pause", since it leads to denialists pretending AGW has stopped, when it actually hasn't. Mann also admits that global warming has continued:

"The rate at which the earth‚Äôs temperature has been rising eased slightly in the past decade, but temperature is still increasing; calling the slowdown a ‚Äúpause‚Äù is false."
http://www.meteo.psu.edu/holocene/public_html/Mann/articles/articles/MannSciAmApr14.pdf

"Making sense of the early-2000s warming slowdown
[...]
We do not believe that warming has ceased [...]
A point of agreement we have with Lewandowsky et al. 26 concerns the unfortunate way in which the recent changes have been framed in terms of GMST having ‚Äú'stalled', 'stopped', 'paused', or entered a 'hiatus'‚Äù. Just exactly how such changes should be referred to is open to debate. Possible choices include 'reduced rate of warming', 'decadal fluctuation' or 'temporary slowdown' ‚Äî all try to convey the primary mechanism involved, which in the recent example is likely to be internal decadal variability."
https://courses.eas.ualberta.ca/eas570/warming_slowdown.pdf



"Furthermore, I have watched this hysteria unfold before, in the 70's and 80's, and no such catastrophe came true.""
"Again, according to men of science, the media and the government of thirty years ago, we should be in an ice age now."

You're amazingly misinformed. Within the scientific community, there were more predictions of imminent global warming than of imminent global cooling (let alone an imminent ice age). And you could hardly call this "hysteria", since the scientific community was careful to mention uncertainties that came with their conclusions:

"The myth of the 1970s global cooling scientific consensus
[...]
There was no scientific consensus in the 1970s that the Earth was headed into an imminent ice age. Indeed, the possibility of anthropogenic warming dominated the peer-reviewed literature even then.
[...]
One way to determine what scientists think is to ask them. This was actually done in 1977 following the severe 1976/77 winter in the eastern United States. "Collectively,‚Äù the 24 eminent climatologists responding to the survey ‚Äútended to anticipate a slight global warming rather than a cooling‚Äù [...]. However, given that an opinion survey does not capture the full state of the science of the time, we conducted a rigorous literature review of the American Meteorological Society‚Äôs electronic archives as well as those of Nature and the scholarly journal archive Journal Storage (JSTOR).
[...]
The survey identified only 7 articles indicating cooling compared to 44 indicating warming. Those seven cooling articles garnered just 12% of the citations."

"The idea of anthropogenic global climate change in the 20th century
[...]
Through the 1970s journalists continued to indulge in sensational talk about the risk of abrupt cooling. In the public mind, the impact of human emissions got mixed up with an entirely separate scientific projection: some experts calculated that in the absence of human influences, orbital shifts in the natural course of the current ice age cycle would bring a gradual cooling over future millennia. In the 1970s, few scientists published peer-reviewed papers about any climate change faster than the thousands of years that glacial ages apparently took to evolve. Of those few papers, only a small fraction concluded that anthropogenic cooling was likely; others discussed cooling and warming factors without coming to a conclusion, and more than half thought it likely that greenhouse warming would eventually dominate. All the experts confessed, however, that this was guesswork; it would take decades of effort to work out a reliable answer. Journalists reported this confession, and the public well understood that no scientific consensus existed.
[...]
In 1979 the U.S. National Academy of Sciences convened a panel, chaired by veteran meteorologist Jule Charney, to look into climate models. They found that any model capable of reproducing something vaguely like the present climate showed a rise in global temperature when its CO2 level was raised. The Charney panel announced they had rather high confidence that as the CO2 level doubled the planet would warm up by about three degrees, plus or minus 50% (i.e., 1.5‚Äì4.5C)."

"Rebuttals to Climate Myths
[...]
However, the most comprehensive study in the 1970s was the 1975 report by the US National Academy of Sciences and National Research Council that concluded, "‚Ä¶ we do not have a good quantitative understanding of our climate machine and what determines its course." This qualified statement is in strong contrast with the current position of the US National Academy of Science: ‚ÄúThe scientific understanding of climate change is now sufficiently clear to justify nations taking prompt action." To compare the handful of cooling predictions in the 1970s (predominantly from media sources, not peer-reviewed literature) to the current scientific consensus endorsing human-caused global warming, is both inappropriate and misleading."
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
+Frances Haypenny

"In fact, they never go back to review if any of their policies work or if harm was caused by them. It doesn't matter."

You mean policies like the Montreal Protocol? Because I remember people going back to review whether that worked. Basically, there was an international treaty known as the "Montreal Protocol" that helped reduce anthropogenic release of CFCs. This helped slow down the decrease in ozone levels. See the following for further discussion:

"Quantifying the ozone and ultraviolet benefits already achieved by the Montreal Protocol"

"Evidence for the effectiveness of the Montreal Protocol to protect the ozone layer"

"Antarctic ozone loss in 1979‚Äì2010: first sign of ozone recovery
[...]
Therefore, our study suggests that Antarctic ozone shows a significant positive trend toward its recovery, and hence, leaves a clear signature of the successful implementation of the Montreal Protocol.
[...]
It will take another fifty years to regain the 1980 level of ozone."


Of course, it helped to have business interests support these regulatory policies. Parallel points may apply to addressing anthropogenic climate change, where the problem may be more easily resolved if business interests support the regulations. For further discussion, see:

"The ozone story: A model for addressing climate change?
[...]
The ozone hole case suggests that nothing will likely happen until a dominant energy producer‚Äîor a consortium of dominant energy producers‚Äîdevelops profitable proprietary alternatives to fossil fuels and other greenhouse gas‚Äìemitting processes. Then, they will change positions to support regulations to drastically reduce greenhouse gas emissions, with the purpose of giving themselves a competitive advantage and significant profits. Public awareness and energy conservation are important, and the public‚Äôs and government representatives‚Äô opinions can put pressure on corporate profits. But it really doesn‚Äôt matter what the public or government representatives want or believe; short-term and long-term corporate profits will drive any decision to greatly limit greenhouse gas emissions."



"As to other kinds of skewing, do you believe that the dangling carrot of government grant money may play a role in how one might respond? Do you think that scientists are uniquely incorruptible?"

Scientists don't just en masse make up conclusions to match their funding sources. Otherwise, most scientists would have stopped citing evidence of AGW under AGW denialist, politically conservative administrations; yet that didn't happen. And if AGW research was just a money-motivated conspiracy, then you would not expect such as broad scientific consensus to hold across scientists from different political/governmental systems; yet such a consensus did arise:
"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"

Nor would you expect the scientific consensus to be supported by multiple lines of evidence, including from evidence from non-government-funded studies, studies that were done before there was much of a political rationale for funding climate science research, and studies that lack a politically-motivated funding rationale; yet we do have such lines of evidence.

Furthermore, you seem to have little understanding of how grant funding is awarded. It isn't awarded based on researchers guaranteeing that their research will support an accepted, pre-determined conclusion. In fact, the research that gets the most attention, prestigious prizes (ex: Nobel prizes), etc. is research that overturns accepted conclusions or breaks new ground, as opposed to just supporting the consensus position. Grant proposals may offer hypotheses to test, but the proposals typically leave open the possibility that the hypotheses will not be confirmed and instead a novel conclusion may be supported/

Anyway, grant funding is awarded based on things such as the proposal writers previously publication record (to show that you can do published research, when given money), preliminary data presented in the proposal, how well the proposal writers know the field (as displayed in their grant proposal), whether the proposal writers have access to the equipment/tools needed for their proposed project, etc. You'd know this if you'd ever bothered to apply for a research grant, spoken with scientists who'd applied for such grants, looked up the grant proposal guidelines (which are freely available on the NIH website, NASA website, etc.), or spoken with grant reviewers. I've done all four of these. Yet instead of doing any of those four things, you seem to be just resorting to the sorts of baseless, paranoid conspiracy theories typical of denialists:

"HIV Denial in the Internet Era
[...]
Deniers argue that because scientists receive grant money, fame, and prestige as a result of their research, it is in their best interest to maintain the status quo [15]. This type of thinking is convenient for deniers as it allows them to choose which authorities to believe and which ones to dismiss as part of a grand conspiracy. In addition to being selective, their logic is also internally inconsistent."

"How the growth of denialism undermines public health
[...]
Characteristics of denialism
Identification of conspiracies: Denialists argue that scientific consensus arises not as a result of independent researchers converging on the same view but instead because researchers have engaged in a complex and secretive conspiracy. They are depicted as using the peer review process to suppress dissent rather than fulfil its legitimate role of excluding work that is devoid of evidence or logical thought."
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text:
+Frances Haypenny

"Look up 'Origin of the 97% Climate Consensus'"
"Nonetheless, here's something to get you started. See:" http://www.forbes.com/sites/jamestaylor/2013/02/13/peer-reviewed-survey-finds-majority-of-scientists-skeptical-of-global-warming-crisis/#6bd6ddaf171b  
"It addresses the consensus myth."
"You're talking about a article about a peer reviewed study that shows that there is no consensus"

Did you really fall for a Forbes article this dumb, from a source as unreliable as James Taylor? My goodness, you might as well trust a tobacco-industry-funded journalist on how smoking is healthy.

Anyway, the study in question doesn't show what Taylor claims it shows. The study was not looking at geoscientists in general, nor does it show most of them don't think that anthropogenic climate change is real. The study was instead largely looking at scientists working for the fossil fuel industry; do you really expect those folks to be unbiased? Taylor misrepresented the study so badly, that the study's authors came out and corrected him:

"First and foremost, our study is not a representative survey. Although our data set is large and diverse enough for our research questions, it cannot be used for generalizations such as ‚Äúrespondents believe ‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚Äúscientists don‚Äôt believe ‚Ä¶‚Äù Our research reconstructs the frames the members of a professional association hold about the issue and the argumentative patterns and legitimation strategies these professionals use when articulating their assumptions. Our research does not investigate the distribution of these frames and, thus, does not allow for any conclusions in this direction. We do point this out several times in the paper, and it is important to highlight it again.
In addition, even within the confines of our non-representative data set, the interpretation that a majority of the respondents believe that nature is the primary cause of global warming is simply not correct. To the contrary: the majority believes that humans do have their hands in climate change, even if many of them believe that humans are not the only cause."
http://scienceblogs.com/denialism/2013/02/15/denialism-from-forbes-courtesy-of-heartland-hack-james-taylor/

This is the study in question:
"Science or Science Fiction? Professionals‚Äô Discursive Construction of Climate Change"

Please try actually reading the study, as opposed to relying on what Taylor and his fellow denialists say about the study. Or at least listen to what the study's author say about the paper.

When you actually looked at a broader picture of the scientific community, the scientific consensus in quite robust, as shown in:
"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"



"The '97%' consensus is a myth and always has been a deception. That number comes from a survey of members of East Anglia - the sample was only 79 scientists, and 76 of them agreed with the man made global warming theory. So if you're concerned about sample size, look to your own side's first and foremost."

There were at least 3 studies showing the 97% figure; so please don't act as if we're limited to just the sample size from the Doran and Zimmerman paper. These issues are further discussed in (especially table 1):

"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"


Furthermore, Doran and Zimmerman had a very good reason for focusing on those 70+ scientists: those were the scientists with the most expertise in the topic. Basically, Doran and Zimmerman wanted to focus on the scientists with the most expertise is climate science, since those scientists were the most likely to have accurate views on climate science. This makes sense both in climate science and other scientific/medical topics. For example, who are you more likely to trust on cancer: someone with just a B.S. in biology who's never done research in cancer, or an MD/PhD oncologist with a long publication record in cancer research? The answer should be obvious. 

Note that having an advanced degree in a subject (ex: PhD) and having an extensive publication records in that subject, are both pretty goody proxy measures for being an expert in that field. that's why for example, funding organizations look at someone's publication record in a field when figuring out whether to award them grant funding in said field. That's why so many studies on consensus use publication record and/or advanced degrees in the topic as proxy measures of expertise.

Doran and Zimmerman make these points quite clear in their paper. Of course, you leave this out, so that you can pretend they have no justification for focusing on those 70+ scientists. Quite unfair of you:

"Examining the Scientific Consensus on Climate Change
[...]
In our survey, the most specialized and knowledgeable respondents (with regard to climate change) are those who listed climate science as their area of expertise and who also have published more than 50% of their recent peer-reviewed papers on the subject of climate change (79 individuals in total). Of these specialists, 96.2% (76 of 79) answered ‚Äúrisen‚Äù to question 1 and 97.4% (75 of 77) answered yes to question 2."



"It is only one example of many. Indeed, there is a very long standing online petition of highly credentialed men and women of science comprised of 30 thousand signatories."

That petition (the Oregon Petition) is nonsense, as discussed in the following source:

"Science Denialism: Evolution and Climate Change
[...]
Note that the wording refers only to ‚Äúcatastrophic heating of the earth‚Äôs atmosphere,‚Äù yet signers of this petition are often represented as questioning the reality of any greenhouse warming.
The marketing of this petition was clever and deceptive.
[...]
There was no effort to determine which of them were active research scientists and no way for outsiders to check the authenticity of the names. An analysis of the list by Scientific American (http://www.scientificamerican.com/podcast/episode.cfm?id=john-rennies-seven-answersto-clima-09-12-03) suggested that roughly 200 atmospheric or climate scientists might have signed."
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text: Atomski, when that stat is cited repeatedly in the media and elsewhere, do they ever get specific, or do they simply allow everyone to believe that 97% of the world's scientists, of whatever type, agree that climate change is primarily human driven and certain to bring about global catastrophe? Do they say that the 97% refers to the members of East Anglia who are going by computer models? Or do they remain silent on that bit? Do they ever present the findings of scientists, i.e., climatologists, meteorologists, et al, that refute those data sets derived from computer models, that climate is changing rapidly and industry / fossil fuels are the main driver? Do they ever show the net benefit of wind turbines, solar panels, etc. or reveal the carbon expelled in the manufacture of turbines and solar panels? Do they demonstrate the accuracy or lack thereof of long term computer models? Do they reveal how many climate related portends of doom have actually come to fruition versus how many have not? Do they show the laymen what traditional energy is employed to operate turbines?  Does any government official, activist, etc. ever propose any solutions which do not entail massive government regulation, energy rationing, taxation, industry killing? Do they ever propose market solutions or say, holding annual energy innovation conventions open to all innovators and presenters seeking private and public funding to develop actual working energy as competent and economical as fossil fuels? Or is the solution always a more intrusive government slinging measures to reduce quality of life everywhere (except for themselves)? Do they ask themselves if China and India will choose to destroy their own economies for the sake of the planet, or do they focus on the first world? Should we go to war with nations who refuse to reduce their emissions? Will the poorest nations ever be allowed to have refrigeration, heating, air conditioning, cars, etc.? Or, as Obama said, will the planet boil over if developing nations have more energy? What of the global cooling hype of the 1970's/80's? Do they decry the falsities and antics of alarmists, or do they only shame so-called 'deniers'? Do they call out the many hypocrisies of their spokesmen, or themselves for being enthusiastic users of all traditional energies while also having greater carbon footprints than the general population? Do you not see the political machinations at play in this issue - irrespective of the science involved? What do you make of politicians and others who demand that 'deniers', no matter how credentialed, be imprisoned? Do you see the irony in the political party who anoints themselves the guardians of true science are also the same people who deny biological differences between the sexes? Do you recognize this sort of politicization of science has happened before in history to catastrophic effect, i.e., genocide?
author: Frances Haypenny

text:
+Frances Haypenny

"when that stat is cited repeatedly in the media and elsewhere, do they ever get specific, or do they simply allow everyone to believe that 97% of the world's scientists, of whatever type, agree that climate change is primarily human driven and certain to bring about global catastrophe?"

They get quite specific, as you would know if you bothered any of the studies on the 97% figure. Seriously, do your homework. The following source will get you started:
"Consensus on consensus: a synthesis of consensus estimates on human-caused global warming"

The consensus position includes the relative contribution of humans to climate change. Also, stop abusing the term "catastrophe"; it's getting tedious seeing denialists like you do that, as discussed in the following source:

"Polluted Discourse: Communication and Myths in a Climate of Denial
[...]
Additionally, we find that catastrophic anthropogenic global warming [CAGW] is essentially a term that is never used in the relevant scientific literature by mainstream sources. Furthermore, in the press it appears to be used exclusively by climate contrarians. The term is typically neither defined nor attributed to a mainstream scientific source. Our conclusion is therefore that CAGW is simply a straw man used by climate contrarians to criticize the mainstream position (50)."



"Do they say that the 97% refers to the members of East Anglia who are going by computer models?"

I already dealt with your mistakes regarding models in climate science. Let me know when you have the wherewithal to address that response. Also, stop pretending that the consensus only includes people in East Anglia; that's disngenuous of you.



"What of the global cooling hype of the 1970's/80's?"

I already dealt with this fabrication of your's, so stop using it. To repeat myself: within the scientific community, there were more predictions of imminent global warming than of imminent global cooling (let alone an imminent ice age). And you could hardly call this "hype", since the scientific community was careful to mention uncertainties that came with their conclusions.



The rest of what you wrote is just baseless rambling, speckled with your made-up political points that have no bearing on the science. Please do better, please cite evidence for your claims and please address evidence/arguments addressed to you. Thanks.
;)
author: Atomsk's Sanakan

text: Please spare me the condescension. I have reviewed the case for man caused warming and the problems therein. I doubt you have seriously sought out evidence to the contrary. And frankly, it's typical that you refer to my points as 'rambling' because you don't want to address the glaring hypocrisies of AGW politics. Because, like most adherents to the alarmist perspective, you are missing the point entirely. To wit: It doesn't matter whether it is wholly true, wholly false, or partially true. This is because, by their own admission, scientists in this milieu contend that none of the measures proposed will make any significant difference even if all industry the world over are halted and fossil fuels are eliminated; this will only impoverish the world. Government cannot alter the climate and will only stall innovation needed to discover new forms of energy with onerous taxation and draconian regulation. Nations like Italy, Ireland and Australia learned this the hard way. The motives of those in power are not necessarily in line with those who are sincerely concerned about any given issue. The carbon credit scam is a major indicator of the true goals of proponents of these kinds of money making / punitive measures. But by all means, if you believe in it, live it, unlike most. Buy carbon credits. Use alternative energy if you can find a company that hasn't folded and run off with the subsidies yet, like so many before. Reduce your own consumption. Party like it's 1799. You'd be in a tiny, tiny minority of people who don't gorge themselves on traditional energy while wagging a finger at everyone else and depriving developing nations energy that actually works.

author: Fakeslimshady

text:
+Patrick Veiltl, good points, but what do you mean by "Climate Change is happening right now." It's been happening for ~4.5 Billion years. Humans have been around for 0.004% of that time.

The Holocene interglacial of the current Ice Age has had 10 warm periods. To say that 9 were natural and the last one was purely caused by human is kind of fishy. Those 10 warm periods happened roughly once every 1,000 years. To think that we would not have had a warm period, without humans, after 9 others went off like clockwork, is not very logical. In other words, nature had more to do with our modern warm period than humans. If you look at the graph of CO2 increases on the year to century scale, there is very little correlation between temperature and CO2.

Now, this notion that Global Warming is bad is all wrong. Where do more people like to live -- Greenland or Java? Look up the population density of each. Global Warming made civilization possible 12,000 years ago. If you dig and understand why, then you will see the lies you've been told.

text:
Billions of humans rely on agriculture for their collective survival. The global climate 12,000 years ago was only sufficient to sustain the comparatively small population at that time. If global temperatures and weather patterns get too far out of whack, the farms that depend on stable temperature and weather patterns will no longer be able to feed all seven and a half billion of us.

I agree that global climate change will not be as apocalyptic as many media outlets and talking heads make it out to be, but we must take steps to ensure that the climate stays stable enough to prevent mass starvation at least.

author: My Name is Gladiator

text:
Uh... climate change is a consequence of global warming. It's not a "changed debate", they refer to two different things. Global warming is the simple fact that the overall energy (that is, temperature, because temperature is just a measure of energy) in the Earth's system is increasing, climate change refers to the effects of global warming, which is, well, that the climate gets screwed up due to the extra energy.

That's because CO2 absorbs infrared radiation and transforms it into heat. If there's more CO2, more of the infrared radiation that the ground emits (any object with any heat does that, that how IR cameras work) is turned into heat rather than escaping into space. It's not that complicated, but you are free to argue against basic chemistry, I guess.

Also, apparently you think that all of established science is a dogma? Like, do you think your phone works on a "dogma being forced"? What about your car?

text:
Why are the things you described bad? I am not saying they aren't but saying "thing is bad" does not make it so. I can tell you why the majority of proposed solutions are. If the goal is to essentially stop the increase of atmospheric CO2, the solution must be the near immediate cessation of its production. This would remove 80 percent of the world's current energy production. And essentially all of its transportation. The cost in life would be measured in the billions.

If you want a compromise solution, where we merely slow the rate of carbon production(but do so by a significant margin), then maybe we can get by with a billion deaths.

Until the folks who are yelling about climate change are willing to discuss solutions that have a reasonable chance of supplying the world's expanding energy needs (nuclear primarily, but also lower emission fuels), at a cost that humanity can afford, the climate change debate will continue to prove a fruitless waste of money. If you think you have a reasonable chance of convincing China's, India's, etc. leadership to shut down coal production and let their people starve, go right ahead.
