[4]" So I would say that the MWP was not considerably warmer than now, even though regions, like the north Atlantic and China, were warmer on average.
author: Christopher Cabanne

text:
That is an alarmist rewriting of history. EVERY where you look, there is evidence of the Medieval warming period being warmer than they claim. They have to claim it was a regional thing or their claim that this is the warmest period in history goes out the window.

The Chinese have kept great records of the cherry blossoms as they consider that an indication of the power of the emperors. During the mwp, the cherry blossoms happened earlier than normal. This was an indication that the temperature warmed up earlier in the year.

In Africa, a study of the glaciers shows the temperature change due to the change in the ratio of two isotopes of carbon. When it is warmer one of them is higher and this showed up during the mwp.

In the south pacific records of rice production shows that it was warmer during the mwp. In South America tree rings prove the mwp affected the far south of the continent.

In the Saragossa sea, deposits of sea weed shows it was warmer during the mwp.

And finally, a PROPER study of the Canadian and northern American forest show they were affected by the mwp.

The only evidence they have that there wasn't a mwp is the study by Michael Mann that has been disproven so strongly everyone but IPCC considers Michael Mann a fraud.

Despite claims otherwise, the entire world was warmer during the mwp than it is today.

I'm just saying we should use what we know will solve the problem rather than throwing billions or trillions at a pipe dream that may never pan out, at least not in our lifetime.
author: Zach Hoskins

text:
Zach Hoskins it is curious why we stick to mostly nuclear reactors that are easy rather than ones that are more efficient, more elegant or more safe. Part of it is the public concern. When something goes wrong at a fission plant, it's very messy (Chernobyl serving as an extreme example. While Fukushima is still being cleaned up, it was much less bad.) so nukes aren't popular even when they are considerably cheaper and safer than the alternatives. There's a lot of NIMBYing out there regarding fusion.

Fusion reactors are dreamy by comparison. A disaster just shuts it off. You need common hydrogen, not very-rare uranium or plutonium. There's no waste that needs to be buried (as per fission) or sequestered / blown off into the air (coal or oil). And we've made fusion reactors before, they're just not sustainable as they produce less energy than is used to drive them.

ITER is supposed to change all that, and they're pretty confident it'll work this time, which is one of the reasons they changed its name from experimental to energy. I agree with you, we should be designing and building better fission reactors, but we shouldn't slow down our persuit of fusion.

text: Crown of Thorns starfish can cause shifts in the ecology of coral reefs. However they do not cause bleaching of the corals themselves. The increased instances of bleaching are attributable to climate change.
author: Sam

text: The more I read your comments the more ignorant I realize you are. The blue sky is caused by shorter wavelengths of light being scattered more. Average global pH levels have decreased significantly (only 0.1 units, although being a logarithmic scale this equates to an increase of 30% in actual acidity).
author: Sam

text: Also net ice melt isn't decreasing ocean temperatures. In fact ocean temperatures are rising (causing bleaching). Coral reefs can keep up with a rise in sea level of 10mm/yr. Current sea level rise is 2-3mm/year, so coral reefs actually aren't actually getting deeper. Although if they were they would still be getting temperature bleached (bleaching can be caused by both too much or too little light). 2-3mm/yr also wouldn't nearly be enough for us to see an great effect on corals over just a few decades anyway (remember even the shallow reefs have depth ranges of ~40m, mesophotic reefs extend much deeper), even if reef structures were not growing to match the rise.
